THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(c)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Dan F. Williamson and Dan F. Williamson and Company,       
Respondents/Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Alfred C. Middleton,       
Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge
Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-011
Heard December 13, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  11, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED


  
    
      
James C. Parham, Jr. and Patricia 
  S. Ravenhorst, both of Greenville, for Appellant/Respondent.
Desa A. Ballard, of W. Columbia, 
  for Respondents/ Appellants.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is a cross-appeal from 
  an action involving unfair trade practices, breach of fiduciary duty, unpaid 
  commissions, and frivolous proceedings.Â  Alfred C. Middleton appeals from the 
  trial courtâ€™s rulings on his motions for summary judgment, directed verdict, 
  judgment notwithstanding the verdict, sanctions, and prejudgment interest.Â  
  He also argues the trial court erred by admitting a brochure into evidence.Â  
  Dan F. Williamson and Dan F. Williamson and Company also appeal, arguing the 
  judge who awarded attorneyâ€™s fees did not have jurisdiction to do so, and in 
  the alternative, that the factors for attorneyâ€™s fees were not met.Â  We affirm 
  in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Williamson, the owner of a material handling 
  and packaging systems company called Dan F. Williamson and Company, employed 
  Middleton as a commissioned salesman.Â  After working for Williamson for several 
  years, Middleton voluntarily terminated his employment and began to work for 
  Peninsula Plastics, Inc., one of Williamsonâ€™s pallet suppliers.Â  
Before leaving Williamsonâ€™s employ, Middleton 
  sold products to Kaltex, Inc., and was due a commission.Â  Middleton claims he 
  sold two thousand pallets, which were to be delivered in four installments of 
  five hundred pallets each; however, Williamson claims Middleton only sold five 
  hundred pallets to Kaltex.Â  In any event, Williamson never paid Middleton any 
  commission for the sale even though it acknowledges that he was owed at least 
  $906.62.
Also prior to leaving his job at Williamson, Middleton 
  asked one of Williamsonâ€™s customers if he could use a photograph that was taken 
  at the customerâ€™s plant to advertise Williamsonâ€™s product in a brochure and 
  on a website.Â  The customer granted him permission, and the photograph was used 
  in Williamsonâ€™s copyrighted brochure.Â  
After Middleton began working for Peninsula Plastics, 
  he was involved in creating an advertisement brochure for Peninsula Plastics.Â  
  The Peninsula Plastics brochure was similar to Williamsonâ€™s brochure in many 
  ways, and the photograph used in Peninsula Plasticsâ€™ brochure appeared to be 
  the same photograph that was used in Williamsonâ€™s brochure, though Middleton 
  denied it was the same photograph. Â Peninsula Plastics also began selling 
  its products to customers who had formerly done business with Williamson.
Williamson filed a complaint against Middleton, 
  alleging causes of action for fraud, constructive fraud, breach of fiduciary 
  duty, and violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act. Middleton 
  denied the allegations and filed a counterclaim for commissions owed and sanctions 
  under the South Carolina Frivolous Proceedings Act.Â  
Prior to trial, Middleton moved to dismiss Williamsonâ€™s 
  claims for fraud, constructive fraud, and unfair trade practices.Â  Williamson 
  voluntarily dismissed its claims for fraud and constructive fraud, and the court 
  denied Middletonâ€™s motion to dismiss Williamsonâ€™s unfair trade practices claim.Â  
  At the close of Williamsonâ€™s case in chief, Middleton moved for a directed verdict 
  as to Williamsonâ€™s remaining causes of action for unfair trade practices and 
  breach of fiduciary duty.Â  The court granted the motion as to the unfair trade 
  practices claim but denied the motion as to the fiduciary duty claim.Â  At the 
  close of Middletonâ€™s case, Middleton again moved for a directed verdict on the 
  claim for breach of fiduciary duty, and the court denied the motion.
The jury returned its verdict in favor of Middleton 
  on Williamsonâ€™s remaining cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty.Â  The 
  jury also found in favor of Middleton on his counterclaim for unpaid commissions 
  in the amount of $906.62 actual damages.Â  Middleton moved for a judgment notwithstanding 
  the verdict and prejudgment interest, both of which were denied.Â  The trial 
  court also denied Middleton relief under the Frivolous Proceedings Act.Â  
After the verdict, the trial judge, Judge Pyle, 
  informed the parties that Middleton was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees but did 
  not set an amount.Â  Judge Pyle asked the parties to resolve the issue among 
  themselves, and he explained that if they could not agree, he would set the 
  amount of attorneyâ€™s fees for them.Â  Because the parties could not resolve the 
  issue of attorneyâ€™s fees, Middleton petitioned the court for assistance.Â  Following 
  a hearing, Judge Miller rather than Judge Pyle, awarded Middleton $35,000.00 
  in attorneyâ€™s fees plus $2,209.27 in costs.Â  This cross-appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Middleton argues the trial court erred (1) 
  denying his motion for a directed verdict as to Williamsonâ€™s claim for breach 
  of fiduciary dutyÂ  (2) denying his motion to exclude evidence regarding Williamsonâ€™s 
  copyrighted company brochure (3) denying his motion for JNOV (4) denying his 
  motion for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs (5) failing to grant his motion for summary 
  judgment as to Williamsonâ€™s claim for unfair trade practices, and (6) denying 
  his motion for prejudgment interest on the amount of damages awarded.Â  Williamson 
  argues Judge Miller first erred in concluding he had jurisdiction to award attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and also erred in awarding fees because the factors supporting an award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees were not met.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Middletonâ€™s Appeal

  a.       
The issue of whether 
  the trial court erred in failing to grant Middletonâ€™s motion for directed verdict 
  on Williamsonâ€™s breach of fiduciary duty claim is moot.  

Middleton first argues 
  the trial court erred in failing to grant his motion for directed verdict on 
  Williamsonâ€™s breach of fiduciary duty claim.Â  We find this issue is moot. 
â€˜â€œA case becomes moot when judgment, if rendered, 
  will have no practical legal effect upon existing controversy,â€™ as â€˜when some 
  event occurs making it impossible for [the reviewing court] to grant effectual 
  relief.â€™â€Â  Southern Bell Tel. & Tel. Co. v. Herlong Pontiac-Chevrolet 
  Buick, Inc., 298 S.C. 299, 301 n.2, 379 S.E.2d 902, 904 n.2 (1989) (brackets 
  in original) (quoting Mathis v. South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 260 
  S.C. 344, 195 S.E.2d 713 (1973)).Â  Moreover, a party may appeal only if it is 
  aggrieved by the result of the trial court.Â  Rule 201(b), SCACR.
In this matter, Middleton received a jury verdict 
  in his favor at trial on the breach of fiduciary duty claim.Â  As a result, Middleton 
  is not an aggrieved party.Â  Therefore, this issue is moot.

  b.       
There was no error in allowing evidence regarding the copyright of the 
  Williamson Brochure. 
   

Middleton next argues the trial court erred in 
  allowing any reference to the Williamson brochure because the state law claims 
  of Williamson are preempted by the Federal Copyright Act of 1976.Â  Specifically, 
  Middleton alleges the Federal Copyright Act preempts and precludes any reference 
  of the copyrighted brochure in support of Williamsonâ€™s claim for breach of fiduciary 
  duty.Â  We disagree.Â  
The admission of evidence is within the broad discretion 
  of the trial court.Â  Manning v. City of Columbia, 297 S.C. 451, 455, 
  377 S.E.2d 335, 336 (1989).Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â Â  
None of Williamsonâ€™s claims against Middleton were 
  based on copyright infringement.Â  Thus, federal preemption is not an issue in 
  this case.Â  Instead, Williamson relied on the brochure, which was very similar 
  to Peninsula Plasticsâ€™ brochure, to support his claim that Middleton breached 
  the fiduciary duty he owed to Williamson.Â  Because the Williamson brochure was 
  relevant to Williamsonâ€™s breach of fiduciary duty claim, we find no error in 
  the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow the brochure into evidence.

  c.       
The trial court did not err in denying Middletonâ€™s motion for JNOV. 
   

 Middletonâ€™s third argument is that the 
  trial court erred in denying his motion for judgment not withstanding the verdict.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
In ruling on a JNOV motion, the trial 
  court must view the evidence and the inferences that can be reasonably drawn 
  therefrom in light most favorable to the party opposing the motion.Â  Steinke 
  v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520 
  S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999). â€œ[T]he trial court should not grant JNOV where the evidence 
  yields more than one inference.Â  An appellate court may not overturn the decision 
  of the trial court . . . if there is any evidence to support the ruling.â€Â  Rogers 
  v. Norfolk Southern Corp., 356 S.C. 85, 92, 588 S.E.2d 87, 90 (2003).Â  
Initially, we note that Middleton received a jury 
  verdict in his favor.Â  Therefore, the appropriate remedy to challenge the sufficiency 
  of a jury award is by additur.Â  See, e.g., Waring v. Johnson, 
  341 S.C. 248, 257, 533 S.E.2d 906, 911 (Ct. App. 2000).
Furthermore, we find sufficient evidence to support 
  the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  Williamson put forth testimony that the only amount owed 
  to Middleton was $906.62, exactly what the jury awarded.Â  Thus, the trial court 
  did not err in denying Middletonâ€™s JNOV motion.

  d.        The trial court 
  properly denied Middletonâ€™s motion for sanctions under the Frivolous Proceedings 
  Act.

Middleton next argues the trial court erred in failing to 
  award him sanctions under the Frivolous Proceedings Act. [1] Â  We disagree.
The determination of whether attorneyâ€™s fees should be awarded 
  under the Frivolous Proceedings Act is treated as one in equity.Â  Hanahan 
  v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 156, 485 S.E.2d 903, 912 (1997).Â  Thus, in reviewing 
  this issue, this court may take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Id.Â  
Section 15-36-20 of the Frivolous Proceedings Act creates 
  a presumption that a person taking part in the initiation or continuation of 
  proceedings acted with a proper purpose â€œif he reasonably believes in the existence 
  of facts upon which his claim is basedâ€ and either (1) reasonably believes under 
  the facts that his claim may be valid under existing or developing law, or (2) 
  relies upon the advice of counsel, sought in good faith and given after full 
  disclosure of all facts within his knowledge.â€Â  Hanahan, 326 S.C. at 
  156-57, 485 S.E.2d at 912.Â  The rule of Hanahan states that â€œwhere a 
  party survives a summary judgment motion, it is not subject to sanctions after 
  a trial on the merits of the surviving claims.â€Â  Id.
Here, Williamson clearly submitted evidence supporting his 
  claims, which is evidenced by the trial courtâ€™s denial of summary judgment on 
  his claim for unfair trade practices and the denial of a directed verdict on 
  his claim for breach of fiduciary duty.Â Â Â  Accordingly, under these facts, we 
  find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Middletonâ€™s motion for sanctions 
  under the Frivolous Proceedings Act.Â  

  e.       The trial court 
  did not err in denying Middletonâ€™s motion for summary judgment on Williamsonâ€™s 
  claim for unfair trade practices.

Middleton asserts the trial court erred in denying the motion 
  for summary judgment on Williamsonâ€™s claim for recovery under the Unfair Trade 
  Practices Act.Â  However, the denial of a motion for summary judgment is not 
  appealable, even after final judgment.Â  Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, 
  Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 168, 580 S.E.2d 440, 444 (2003).Â  We therefore decline 
  to address this issue.

  f.         The trial 
  court erred in denying Middletonâ€™s motion for prejudgment interest on the unpaid 
  commissions.

Middleton asserts the trial court erred in not awarding prejudgment 
  interest on the award for unpaid commissions.Â  We agree.
 Section 34-31-20(A) of the South Carolina Code of Laws 
  (1976) provides:

In all cases of accounts stated and in all cases wherein 
  any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained and, being due, shall draw interest 
  according to law, the legal interest shall be at the rate of eight and three-fourths 
  percent per annum.

Prejudgment interest is available only when the â€œsum is certain 
  or capable of being reduced to certainty.â€Â  Lee v. Thermal Engineering, 
  352 S.C. 81, 88, 572 S.E.2d 298, 305 (Ct. App. 2002).
In this matter, the amount recovered by Middleton 
  for unpaid commissions, $906.62, was an amount conceded by Williamson from the 
  outset of the litigation.Â  Although Middleton sought money in addition to this 
  conceded amount, the $906.62 actually awarded to him was a sum certain that 
  Williamson admittedly owed. Therefore, the trial court erred in not awarding 
  prejudgment interest.
  II.            Williamsonâ€™s Appeal
Williamson appeals the trial courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  Initially, Williamson alleges Judge Miller did not have jurisdiction 
  to entertain Middletonâ€™s motion for attorneyâ€™s fees because Judge Pyle retained 
  exclusive jurisdiction over the matter.Â  Secondarily, Williamson contends Judge 
  Miller erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees because the factors supporting an award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees were not satisfied.Â  We agree that Judge Miller did not have 
  jurisdiction to entertain the motion for attorneyâ€™s fees and remand the issue 
  to Judge Pyle. 
Where a judge has jurisdiction to hear a matter 
  and the matter is heard before him, he entertains jurisdiction until his decision 
  is rendered.Â  First Carolinas Joint Stock Land Bank of Columbia v. Knotts, 
  191 S.C. 384, 395, 1 S.E.2d 797, 808 (1939).Â  Until written and entered, the 
  trial judge retains discretion to change his mind and amend his oral ruling 
  accordingly.Â  Ford v. State Ethics Commâ€™n, 344 S.C. 642, 647, 545 S.E.2d 
  821, 823 (2001).Â  The written order is the trial judgeâ€™s final order and as 
  such constitutes the final judgment of the court.Â  Id.Â  A trial judge 
  who controlled the case below retains control of any post trial motions.Â  See, 
  e.g.,Â  In re Beard, 359 S.C. 351, 358, 597 S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. 
  App. 2004) (holding a trial judge loses jurisdiction over a case when the time 
  to file post-trial motions has elapsed).Â Â  
Judge Pyle presided over the trial in this matter.Â  
  Following the jury verdict, Middleton moved for attorneyâ€™s fees under the Frivolous 
  Proceedings Act, but the trial judge denied this motion.Â  However, Judge Pyle 
  ruled Middleton was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees a result of the verdict in his 
  favor on the commissions issue.Â  Judge Pyle specifically undertook consideration 
  of the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees, asking Middletonâ€™s counsel if he had a figure 
  â€œin mindâ€ for the amount that ought be awarded.Â  Before counsel responded, Judge 
  Pyle stated:

Why donâ€™t you do this?Â  Why donâ€™t you submit to [Williamsonâ€™s 
  counsel] what you perceive to be an appropriate amount?Â  See if you can resolve 
  it between the two of you.Â  And if you canâ€™t resolve it, then submit it to me, 
  and I will resolve the problem for you.

Judge Pyle then reiterated, â€œAll right.Â  If you 
  canâ€™t get together and resolve it, then let me know . . . and I will resolve 
  it for you.â€ 
In so stating, Judge Pyle assumed jurisdiction 
  until the final order was entered in the matter.Â  See First Carolinas 
  Joint Stock Land Bank of Columbia, 191 S.C. at 395, 1 S.E.2d at 808.Â  Because 
  the order was never reduced to a final order, Judge Pyle retained exclusive 
  jurisdiction over the award of the attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Id.Â  As a result, 
  we hold Judge Miller lacked jurisdiction to enter the award of attorneyâ€™s fees 
  for Middleton.Â  
CONCLUSION
We  AFFIRM the trial courtâ€™s denial of Middletonâ€™s 
  motions for directed verdict, JNOV, sanctions under the Frivolous Proceedings 
  Act, and summary judgment.Â  We also AFFIRM the trial courtâ€™s decision to allow 
  evidence regarding the Williamson brochure. Â However, we REVERSE the trial courtâ€™s 
  denial of prejudgment interest on Middletonâ€™s claim for commissions, and we 
  REVERSE and REMAND Judge Millerâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees.
AFFIRMED in part, REVERSED in part, and REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-36-10 through 15-36-50 (Supp. 2003).

PER CURIAM:Â  Virginia Wheeler appears a 
  family court order terminating her parental rights to her minor child Christina.Â  
  The family court terminated Wheelerâ€™s parental rights based on her failure to 
  support and meaningfully visit with her child and a finding that termination 
  of parental rights was in Christinaâ€™s best interest.
Pursuant to Ex parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 
  354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), Wheelerâ€™s counsel attached to the record of the family 
  court proceedings an affidavit stating his belief that the pending appeal lacks 
  merit.Â  The affidavit, along with the transcript of the merits hearing, was 
  served by first-class mail on Wheeler at two different addresses.Â  Wheeler did 
  not file a pro se response.
After reviewing the transcript in its entirety, 
  we hold there are no meritorious issues warranting additional briefing.Â  Accordingly, 
  we affirm the family courtâ€™s decision to terminate Wheelerâ€™s parental rights. [1] 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ.,

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

PER CURIAM:Â  Clifton W. appeals his conviction 
  for unlawful possession of a pistol.Â  Cliftonâ€™s appellate counsel has petitioned 
  to be relieved as counsel, stating she has reviewed the record and has concluded 
  any appeal would be without merit.Â  The issue briefed by counsel concerns whether 
  the conviction should be vacated as the product of an unlawful search.Â  Clifton 
  has filed not filed any documents on his own behalf with this court.
After a review of the record as required 
  by Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967), and State v. Williams, 
  305 S.C. 116, 406 S.E.2d 357 (1991), we hold there are no directly appealable 
  issues that are arguable on their merits. 
  [1] Â  Accordingly, we dismiss the appeal and grant counselâ€™s petition to

APPEAL DISMISSED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  During the same proceeding, Clifton also pled guilty to assault 
    and battery of a high and aggravated nature, and we hold there are no directly 
    appealable issues of arguable merit resulting from this conviction.

 
   
    [2] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rules 215 
    and 220(b)(2), SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Willie Earl Dodd, Employee,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Exide Battery Corporation, Employer, and Risk Enterprise Management, 
        Ltd.,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
John W. Kittredge, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-014
Heard December 14, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael M. Farry and David A. 
  Wilson, both of Greenville, for Appellants.
Eddie R. Harbin, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This is a workersâ€™ compensation 
  case.Â  The single commissioner found the claimant Willie Earl Dodd, an assembly 
  line worker, sustained a compensable injury by accident on January 3, 1995, 
  while employed by the Appellant Exide Battery Corporation.Â  The single commissioner 
  described the injury as one in which repetitive trauma caused Dodd to suffer 
  â€œbi-lateral carpal tunnel syndrome to both wrists and hands.â€Â  The full commission 
  adopted the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  The circuit court affirmed.Â  
  Exide and its insurance carrier, Risk Enterprise Management, Ltd., appeal.Â  
  We affirm. 
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s 
  holding that the two-year statute of limitations prescribed by S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 42-15-40 (Supp. 2003) did not bar Doddâ€™s claim.Â  Dodd, as found by the commission, 
  suffered a repetitive trauma injury, an â€œinjury by accidentâ€ under the workersâ€™ 
  compensation act.Â Â  Pee Dee v. AVM, 352 S.C. 167, 174, 573 S.E.2d 785, 
  789 (2002).Â  In cases involving repetitive trauma, the statute of limitations 
  runs from the date of last exposure.Â  Schurlknight v. City of Charleston, 
  352 S.C. 175, 178-179, 574 S.E.2d 194, 195 (2002); 
  [1]  see also White v. Med. Univ. of S.C., 355 S.C. 560, 565-66, 
  586 S.E.2d 157, 160-61 (2003).Â  Here, the last day of exposure ─ when 
  Dodd engaged in the repetitive activity that caused his injury ─ occurred 
  on January 31, 1996, the last day Dodd worked for Exide.Â  
2.Â  We do not address the issue, raised in Appellantsâ€™ 
  brief, of whether Exide received notice of Doddâ€™s accident within ninety days 
  of its occurrence as required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-20 (Supp. 2003).Â Â  The 
  trial court did not address the issue and Appellants never specifically raised 
  it to the trial court.Â  Winter v. U.S. Fidelity & Guar. Co., 240 
  S.C. 561, 573, 126 S.E.2d 724, 730 (1962); Gaddy v. Douglass, 359 S.C. 
  329, 350, 597 S.E.2d 12, 23 (Ct. App. 2004); cf. State v. Bailey, 
  298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) (holding the making of â€œstandard motionsâ€ 
  at trial does not preserve an issue for appellate review); 4 C.J.S. Appeal 
  and Error Â§ 213, at 293 (1993) (â€œAt the very least, the matter must have 
  definitely been called to the attention of the trial court sufficiently to obtain 
  a ruling thereon.â€).Â Â Â  
3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  We find no error in the circuit courtâ€™s 
  holding that the full commission did not err in remanding Doddâ€™s carpal tunnel 
  claim to the single commissioner for additional evidence.Â  See S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 42-17-50 (Supp. 2003)Â  (authorizing the commission, among other things, 
  to receive further evidence and rehear the parties); Spearman v. F.S. Royster 
  Guano Co., 188 S.C. 393, 403-04, 199 S.E. 530, 535 (1938) (stating the commission 
  possesses broad authority to take additional testimony); see also 25A 
  S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-707(A) (Supp. 2003) (authorizing the commission, in 
  its discretion, to order additional evidence when necessary for the completion 
  of the record); Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 521, 415 
  S.E.2d 841, 844 (Ct. App. 1992) (holding the commission, as the fact finder 
  in a workersâ€™ compensation case, has the authority to receive further evidence).
 4.Â  We agree with the circuit courtâ€™s 
  holding that substantial evidence supports the finding by the commission linking 
  Doddâ€™s carpal tunnel syndrome with his employment at Exide.Â  An appellate court 
  must affirm the findings of the commission if they are supported by substantial 
  evidence.Â  Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 
  S.C. 276, 289, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610-11 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Doddâ€™s work on the assembly 
  line involved repetitive grasping, gripping, squeezing, and breaking grids.Â  
  On April 1, 1996, just a little over two months after Dodd left Exideâ€™s employ 
  and some fifteen to eighteen months after he began experiencing numbness and 
  tingling in his fingers, a physician diagnosed Doddâ€™s condition as carpal tunnel 
  syndrome.Â  A nerve study conducted by a physical therapist revealed Dodd suffered 
  from a â€œdemyelinating lesion of the Median nerves in the carpal tunnel [and] 
  distally at the wrists, bilaterally.â€Â  An orthopedist physician opined the cause 
  of Doddâ€™s carpal tunnel syndrome was most probably due to the type of work Dodd 
  performed with Exide.Â  
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1]  Appellants attempt to distinguish Schurlknight on the grounds 
    that the commission found Dodd sustained an injury by accident, not a repetitive 
    stress injury.Â  The commission, however, also found that Doddâ€™s injuries â€œwere 
    caused by repetitive trauma.â€Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
David Carter,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-015
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Senior Assistant Appellate Defender Wanda P. Hagler, Office 
  of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney GeneralÂ  Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R. J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  John R. Justice, of Chester, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  David Carter appeals his conviction 
  for armed robbery, arguing the circuit court (1) lacked subject matter jurisdiction 
  because Carterâ€™s indictment was insufficient; (2) erred in admitting evidence 
  allegedly obtained unlawfully through a warrantless search; and (3) erred in 
  allowing the State to make remarks in its closing statement that were allegedly 
  prejudicial against Carter.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Carter and an acquaintance, Marvin Thompson, were 
  charged with armed robbery in connection with the June 28, 2002, robbery of 
  the Stop and Shop convenience store in Lancaster. 
The day after Carter was incarcerated on the charges, 
  he asked a sheriffâ€™s deputy to procure some papers from his home.Â  He specifically 
  instructed the deputy to go to the home, enter through its unlocked back door, 
  and go down the hall and through the kitchen to the living room, where a black 
  bag was located that contained the papers Carter sought.Â  The deputy complied, 
  and while walking through the kitchen saw a handwritten â€œstick upâ€ note stating 
  â€œI got a gun.Â  Put all of the money in the bag or I will shoot you.Â  Then lay 
  on the floor.â€Â  The deputy retained the note as evidence. Â At trial, Carter 
  sought to suppress the â€œstick upâ€ note, claiming it was seized through an illegal 
  search of his home.Â  The court allowed the â€œstick upâ€ note in evidence.Â  
Thompson pled guilty prior to Carterâ€™s trial, and 
  in so doing implicated Carter in the robbery.Â  Thompson subsequently, however, 
  retreated from his guilty plea statements implicating Carter.Â  Thompson was 
  willing to testify for Carterâ€”that Carter was not involved in the armed robberyâ€”but 
  he was concerned the State would retaliate against him for his change in position.Â  
  The State informed the trial court that it had no intention of retaliating against 
  Thompson, and in this regard, the State granted Thompson immunity from perjury.Â  
  Thompson did testify for Carter and claimed Carter had not been involved in 
  the robbery.Â  In its closing statements, the State suggested that Thompson, 
  in light of the grant of immunity, had nothing to lose in testifying for his 
  friend, Carter. Carterâ€™s counsel interrupted the Stateâ€™s argument and disagreed 
  with the Stateâ€™s use and characterization of the grant of immunity to Thompson, 
  stating â€œYour Honor, [the State] mischaracterized that totally about what he 
  had to lose if Your Honor remembers back to yesterday, thatâ€™s, in fact, not 
  the case.â€Â Â  The court allowed the State to continue its argument.
Carter was convicted on the armed robbery charge.Â  This appeal 
  followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
DISCUSSION
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Subject Matter Jurisdiction
Carter first argues the indictment 
  was insufficient to confer subject matter jurisdiction because the it cited 
  the incorrect statutory subsection and also failed to specifically alleged a 
  â€œcarrying awayâ€ of property.Â  We disagree.
â€œAn indictment is sufficient if 
  the offense is stated with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable 
  the court to know what judgment to pronounce, and the defendant to know what 
  he is called upon to answer and whether he may plead an acquittal or conviction 
  thereon.â€Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 374, 580 S.E.2d 785, 791 (Ct. 
  App. 2003).Â  â€œThe true test of the sufficiency of an indictment is not whether 
  it could be made more definite and certain, but whether it contains the necessary 
  elements of the offense intended to be charged and sufficiently apprises the 
  defendant of what he must be prepared to meet.â€Â  Browning v. State, 320 
  S.C. 366, 368, 465 S.E.2d 358, 359 (1995).Â  â€œ[I]n viewing the sufficiency of 
  an indictment we must look at the issue with a practical eye in view of the 
  surrounding circumstances.â€Â  State v. Gunn, 313 S.C. 124, 130, 437 S.E.2d 
  75, 78 (1993).
Here, the caption twice stated Carter 
  was indicted for â€œÂ§ 16-11-0330(B)Â  ARMED ROBBERY.â€Â  At trial, the parties agreed 
  that the indictment incorrectly referred to subsection (B) of section 16-11-330, 
  which addresses â€œattempted armed robbery,â€ instead of subsection (A), which 
  addresses â€œarmed robbery.â€Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330 (1976).Â Â  
  The court allowed the State to amend the typographical error at trial over Carterâ€™s 
  objection.Â  We find that this minor alteration merely corrected a typographical 
  error.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-19-100 (2003). 
Additionally, the indictment stated:

That David Carter did in Lancaster County on or about June 
  28, 2002, while armed with a deadly weapon, to wit:Â  pistol, feloniously take 
  from the person or presence of STOP AND SHOP such goods or monies being described 
  herein as follows:Â  money with intent to deprive the owner permanently of such 
  property.

Carter argues the indictment fails because it does not include 
  the words â€œcarrying awayâ€ to demonstrate the requisite element of asportation, 
  which means â€œtaking of an object with felonious intent.â€Â  Locke v. State, 
  341 S.C. 54, 57, 533 S.E.2d 324, 325 (2000).Â  However, we find that the indictmentâ€™s 
  language stating â€œfeloniously take from the person or presence ofâ€ the store 
  inherently includes the element of asportation.Â  See Id. at 56, 
  533 S.E.2d at 325 (â€œIndictment language â€˜taking of goods and/or monies from 
  the person or presence ofâ€™ alleged the substance of asportation . . . was sufficient 
  because asportation merely meant the taking of an object with felonious intentâ€).
Viewing this indictment 
  with a practical eye and considering the surrounding circumstances, we find 
  it sufficiently apprised Carter of the specific crime for which he was charged.Â  
  In particular, we note the indictment stated he was charged with â€œARMED ROBBERYâ€ 
  and included the statute, albeit with a typographical error concerning the subsection 
  which the court was entitled to correct.Â  Furthermore, the body of the indictment 
  included the details of the circumstances Carter was called upon to defend and 
  alleges the substance of the crime charged, including the requisite element 
  of asportation.Â  Thus, we find the indictment sufficient to confer subject matter 
  jurisdiction.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Admission of Evidence
Carter argues the court 
  erred in allowing the â€œstick upâ€ note into evidence because it was seized pursuant 
  to a warrantless search.Â  We disagree, for we find evidence to support the trial 
  judgeâ€™s findings.Â  State v. Brockman, 339 S.C. 57, 528 S.E.2d 661 (2000) 
  (the standard of review in Fourth Amendment search and seizure cases is limited 
  to determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s findings, and 
  the appellate court may reverse only where there is clear error).Â  
â€œ[O]bjects falling within the plain view 
  of a law enforcement officer who is rightfully in position to view these objects 
  are subject to seizure and may be introduced in evidence.â€Â  State v. Brown, 
  289 S.C. 581, 588, 347 S.E.2d 882, 886 (1986).Â  Here, Carter admittedly asked 
  the officer to enter his home, specifically the kitchen area, where the note 
  was left open on a table.Â  Concerning the conspicuous nature of the kitchen 
  table, Carter acknowledged that anyone present in his kitchen, including law 
  enforcement, would see â€œanythingâ€ on his table.Â  These facts satisfy the plain 
  view exception to the warrant requirement.Â  State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 
  344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 352-53 (Ct. App. 2004) (plain view exception to warrant 
  requirement requires that the initial intrusion be lawful, the discovery of 
  the evidence be inadvertent, and the incriminating nature of the evidence be 
  immediately apparent).Â  
III.Â Â Â  The Stateâ€™s Closing Statement
Carter alleges the circuit court 
  erred in permitting the State to make a comment questioning the motive of Thompson, 
  the co-defendant witness who had pled guilty, been granted immunity, and then 
  testified favorably toward Carter.
In the present case, Carterâ€™s counsel asserted, 
  â€œYour Honor, [the State] mischaracterized that totally about what he had to 
  lose if Your Honor remembers back to yesterday, thatâ€™s, in fact, not the case.â€Â  
  This interruption of the Stateâ€™s closing statement can hardly be said to constitute 
  a specific objection or a request for relief.Â Â  Even assuming counselâ€™s statement 
  may properly be construed as an objection, there is clearly no request for relief.Â  
  Accordingly, we find the issue unpreserved for appellate review.Â  See 
  State v. Black, 319 S.C. 515, 521, 462 S.E.2d 311, 315 (Ct. App. 1995) 
  (â€œThe proper course to be pursued when counsel makes an improper argument is 
  for opposing counsel to immediately object and to have a record made of the 
  statements or language complained of and to ask the court for a distinct ruling 
  thereonâ€); State v. Patterson, 324 S.C. 5, 17, 482 S.E.2d 760, 766 (1997) 
  (holding a â€œgeneral objection that does not specify the particular ground on 
  which the objection is based is insufficient to preserve a question for reviewâ€).Â  

AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Danny Averette,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Elaine Averette Browning,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Thomas Kemmerlin, Master in Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-016
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
V. M. Manning Smith, of Beaufort, for Appellant.
J. Thomas Mikell, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal 
  from an order finding Elaine Averette Browning in contempt for building a fence 
  on property belonging to her brother, Danny Averette, as determined in an order 
  from a prior adjudication.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
M.C. Averette owned lots 9, 10, 11, and 
  12 of the North View Subdivision located on Port Royal Island in Beaufort County.Â  
  On December 31, 1992, he transferred the property to his son, Danny Averette, 
  and his daughter, Elaine Averette Browning, by deed. Of the four lots, Elaine 
  was granted lot 12 and the â€œ[w]esternmost 60 feetâ€ of lot 11.Â  The deed stated 
  that the portion of lot 11 deeded to Elaine was bounded on the west by â€œan unnamed 
  18 foot road separating it from lot 12,â€ and on the east by the remaining portion 
  of lot 11, which was conveyed to Danny.Â  Danny was simultaneously granted lots 
  9 and 10, as well as the remaining portion of lot 11, described as â€œthat portion 
  remaining of said lot after the Westernmost 60 feet of said lot is simultaneously 
  conveyed to Elaine A. Browning.â€Â  Both deeds reference the subdivision plat, 
  which illustrates an 18-foot road running between lots 11 and 12.Â  This dispute 
  arose because the 18-foot road did not exist and lot 11 was actually bounded 
  on its west by lot 12.Â  Danny brought an action to have the master-in-equity 
  declare the true boundary.Â  
The master divided the property as follows:

Even though there is no 18 foot road, I find that I can 
  best effect the grantorâ€™s wishes by following exactly what he says about the 
  division of Lot eleven:Â  [Elaine] is entitled to Lot 12 as shown on the plat 
  of Gasque and Associates 7/20/98 and the [Danny] is entitled to Lot 10 as shown 
  on that plat and other plats introduced into evidence.Â  Lot 11 shall be divided 
  as provided by the deeds quoted above between [Danny] and [Elaine]:Â  [Elaine] 
  shall have the Westernmost 60 feet of Lot 11 and [Danny] shall have the Easternmost 
  139 feet, more or less, making the line of division that [sic] found on Gasqueâ€™s 
  plat referred to above as the line running N33Âº26â€™36â€™â€™E.

Following the order, Elaine built a wooden fence approximately eighteen 
  feet east of the dividing line marked N33Âº26â€™36â€™â€™E on the Gasque plat.Â  Upon 
  motion to hold Elaine in contempt, the master determined that the fence was 
  a violation of its order, Elaine was aware of the order, and her actions constituted 
  contempt of court. [1] Â  The court ordered the removal 
  of the fence within thirty days.Â  Elaine appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Elaine argues 
  that the trial court erred in its determination of the boundary line.Â  However, 
  she did not appeal the May 10, 2000 order of the trial court, which determined 
  the boundary lines of the respective properties.Â  Therefore, the boundary lines 
  articulated in that order are the law of the case.Â  See Tolerâ€™s Cove 
  Homeowners Assâ€™n v. Trident Constr. Co., 355 S.C. 605, 610, 586 S.E.2d 581, 
  584 (2003) (stating a finding that neither party has appealed is the law of 
  the case); Priester v. Brabham, 230 S.C. 201, 203, 95 S.E.2d 167, 168 
  (1956) (stating an unappealed decision, â€œright or wrong, is now the law of the 
  caseâ€).Â  
Alternatively, Elaineâ€™s remaining arguments assert that the May 10, 
  2003 order is ambiguous and lacks clarity such that it is unenforceable.Â  We 
  disagree. [2] 
â€œThis court will reverse a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding contempt 
  only if it is without evidentiary support or is an abuse of discretion.Â Â  An 
  abuse of discretion can occur where the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an 
  error of law.â€Â  First Union Natâ€™l Bank v. First Citizens Bank and Trust Co., 
  346 S.C. 462, 466, 551 S.E.2d 301, 303 (Ct. App. 2001) (citations omitted).
â€œIt is well settled that contempt results from willful disobedience 
  of a court order; and before a person may be held in contempt, the record must 
  be clear and specific as to acts or conduct upon which the contempt is based.â€Â  
  Cheap-Oâ€™s Truck Stop, Inc. v. Cloyd,  350 S.C. 596, 607, 567 S.E.2d 
  514, 519 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting State v. Bevilacqua, 316 S.C. 
  122, 129, 447 S.E.2d 213, 217 (Ct. App. 1994)).Â  â€œA willful act is defined as 
  one â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something 
  the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law 
  requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard 
  the law.â€™â€Â  Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Social Services v. Padgett, 296 
  S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988) (quoting Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 
  1434 (5th Ed. 1979)).Â  However, â€œ[o]ne may not be convicted of contempt for 
  violating a court order which fails to tell him in definite terms what he must 
  do.â€Â  Welchel v. Boyter, 260 S.C. 418, 421, 196 S.E.2d 496, 498 (1973). 

We find the May 10, 2003 order of the master â€œmaking the line of division 
  that [sic] found on Gasqueâ€™s plat referred to above as the line running N33Âº26â€™36â€™â€™E,â€ 
  clearly and unambiguously describes the dividing line between Elaine and Dannyâ€™s 
  property.Â  The fact that the master granted Danny the easternmost 139 feet, 
  â€œmore or less,â€ clearly refers to the inches the master excluded in making his 
  calculation. [3] Â Â  Moreover, 
  we find that Elaineâ€™s erection of the fence approximate eighteen feet east of 
  that dividing line to be a willful violation of the order.Â Â  For these reasons, 
  the contempt order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur. 

 
   
    [1]  Based on the statements in the masterâ€™s order, a hearing on the motion 
    was held on October 22, 2001.Â  A transcript from that hearing does not appear 
    in the record on appeal.Â  

 
   
    [2]  Arguably, this issue is not preserved for appeal.Â  Without the transcript 
    of the hearing, we are unable to discern what issues were raised to the master.Â  
    Further, the masterâ€™s order does not specifically find the previous order 
    unambiguous.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 
    S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for 
    the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the 
    trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  

 
   
    [3] Additionally, the deeds granting the property to both Elaine and Danny 
    excluded the inches and just used feet in measuring the division of the property.Â  
    Only the plats introduced into evidence set forth the distances between the 
    property lines and the distances between the disputed lines using feet and 
    inches.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
BB&T of South Carolina a/k/a Branch Banking and Trust Company,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Lisa Smith Kidwell and William Brian Kidwell d/b/a Signature Residential 
        Mortgage and John Franklin,        Defendants,
Of Whom John H. Franklin is       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Robert L. Couch, Master in Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-017
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
John W. Ray, of 

Greenville

, for Appellant.
David G. Ingalls, of 

Spartanburg

, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an ongoing dispute 
  between two competing mortgagees originating from a mortgage foreclosure action.Â  
  In a previous appeal, this court determined that BB&T of South Carolina 
  held first-lien status.Â  On remand, the master-in-equity ordered John H. Franklin, 
  the other mortgagee, to hold the rents from the property in trust and to pay 
  BB&T the principal and interest owed.Â  The order made specific findings 
  regarding the amount owed, the rate of interest and the date to which interest 
  would accrue, and the time for payment.Â  When Franklin failed to pay BB&T 
  the entire amount owed, BB&T filed a rule to show cause seeking to hold 
  Franklin in contempt.Â  The master reserved jurisdiction over the contempt action, 
  and pursuant to Franklinâ€™s request, ordered BB&T to provide further information 
  and witnesses.Â Â  BB&T appeals.Â  We reverse. 
  [1] Â  
FACTS
This 
  appeal stems from an action brought by BB&T to foreclose on real property 
  owned by Lisa and William Kidwell.Â  BB&T named John H. Franklin as a necessary 
  party and defendant.Â  Franklin counterclaimed alleging he had an $85,000 mortgage 
  on the property that was entitled to priority over BB&Tâ€™s mortgage.Â  The 
  master-in-equity determined the Kidwells were liable on both BB&Tâ€™s mortgage 
  and Franklinâ€™s mortgage and ordered a public sale of the property.Â  Further, 
  the master determined that Franklin was entitled to first-lien status and therefore 
  priority over BB&Tâ€™s mortgage.Â  BB&T appealed the masterâ€™s ruling.Â  
  Pending the outcome of the appeal, the master stayed the public sale and ordered 
  that rents from the property be collected and held in trust.Â  On appeal, this 
  court reversed, finding BB&T was entitled to first-lien status and remanded 
  the case to the master â€œfor a recalculation of the total sums due BB&T and 
  Franklin.â€Â  See BB&T of South Carolina v. Kidwell, 350 S.C. 
  382, 391, 565 S.E.2d 316, 321 (Ct. App. 2002) (affirming the masterâ€™s award 
  of prejudgment interest on Franklinâ€™s mortgage, but reversing the masterâ€™s determination 
  that Franklinâ€™s mortgage was entitled to priority and remanding for recalculation 
  of sums due BB&T and Franklin). 
On remand, the master determined 
  that the real property subject to the BB&T and Franklin mortgages had been 
  sold at a private sale by agreement of the parties and that the sale proceeds 
  had been held in the attorneysâ€™ trust accounts.Â  Further, the master determined 
  that all rents from the property were collected and were being held in trust 
  by Franklinâ€™s attorney.Â  The master ordered Franklin to pay to BB&T $106,065.24, 
  which constituted the principal as well as the interest that had accrued through 
  January 17, 2001, the date of trial.Â  The master also ordered Franklin to pay 
  to BB&T interest in the amount of $27.27 per day for each day following 
  the trial through August 29, 2002, the date of the order on remand.Â  These interest 
  payments totaled $16,062.03.Â  Additionally, Franklin was ordered to pay interest 
  in the amount of $27.27 per day for each day after August 29, 2002 through the 
  date of receipt of the order by BB&Tâ€™s counsel or â€œthe ending of any appeal 
  from this Order, by written notice of the Defendant Franklin or Order of the 
  appellate courts, whichever shall last occur.â€Â Â  All rents from the property 
  were ordered to be held in trust pending a further order or immediately paid 
  over to BB&T for payment of the principal, interest, and attorneyâ€™s fees 
  due.Â  
Following the masterâ€™s order, 
  Franklin sent a copy of an undated and unfiled â€œNotice of Intent to Appealâ€ 
  to BB&T.Â  After repeated requests from BB&T for either a filed appeal 
  or written notice that Franklinâ€™s appeal had ended, Franklin notified BB&T 
  that he abandoned his appeal on October 15, 2002.Â  After BB&T received written 
  notice that Franklinâ€™s appeal had been abandoned, BB&Tâ€™s counsel disbursed 
  the proceeds held in escrow.Â  According to BB&T, after disbursing the funds 
  held in escrow, a shortfall of $3,313.42 remained on the money owed BB&T.Â  
  BB&T requested that Franklin utilize the rents collected from the property 
  to pay that sum.Â  
On October 24, 2002, BB&T filed a 
  rule to show cause seeking to hold Franklin in contempt for failing to provide 
  a detailed accounting of rents and failing to apply the rents towards satisfaction 
  of the debt owed to BB&T.Â  
On October 25, 2002, Franklin sent BB&T 
  a response [2]  and a subpoena 
  requesting that BB&T produce all records concerning â€œa mortgage loan to 
  Lisa S. Kidwell and William Brian Kidwell dated November 5, 1999.â€Â  BB&T 
  filed a motion to quash the subpoena alleging that the subpoena was improper 
  because BB&T was a party, that the doctrine of res judicata barred Franklin 
  from asserting claims, that Franklin should be estopped from engaging in discovery, 
  and that service was invalid.Â  BB&T also filed a return to Franklinâ€™s response 
  asserting, among other allegations, that the issues raised in the response were 
  barred because they had been previously litigated.Â  On November 22, 2002, BB&T 
  filed a â€œCertificate of No Objection, Return nor Denial to Rule to Show Cause,â€ 
  which alleged that Franklinâ€™s response to the rule was unfiled and arguing that 
  Franklinâ€™s request for a recalculation of interest was affirmative relief which 
  had been fully decided by the 2001 order, 2002 opinion of this court, and 2002 
  order on remand.Â Â  Additionally, BB&Tâ€™s certificate stated that by agreement 
  of the parties a hearing before the equity court on the rule to show cause was 
  set for November 22, 2002.
At the hearing, the parties 
  addressed BB&Tâ€™s motion to quash the subpoena.Â  The master asked Franklin 
  whether he had received the information requested.Â  Franklin responded that 
  based on the information he received, he was not clear when the mortgage on 
  the property had been paid off.Â  Franklin asserted that he was only liable to 
  BB&T for rents on the property up to the date the mortgage was paid off, 
  and BB&T conceded that point.Â  Franklin suggested that the mortgage was 
  paid off prior to the August 29, 2002 date that the master determined interest 
  was due through.Â  BB&T asserted, however, that the issue was barred because 
  Franklin made no objection, made no post-trial motion, or appealed from the 
  order on remand, which set the dates interest would accrue through.Â  The master 
  concluded the hearing by ordering BB&T to provide the court with information 
  as to when BB&Tâ€™s mortgage account was credited with payment and how much 
  BB&T received.Â  
The masterâ€™s written order determined 
  that he retained jurisdiction over the matter, ordered BB&T to identify 
  the person who was the keeper of payments and disbursals made on the Kidwell 
  account, and ordered that person to be a witness at the merits hearing.Â  From 
  this order, BB&T appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
BB&T argues the master erred in ordering BB&T to 
  identify the person who was the keeper of payments and disbursals made on the 
  Kidwell account and in ordering that person to be a witness at the merits hearing.Â  
  Specifically, BB&T contends that because Franklin never appealed from the 
  masterâ€™s order on remand, the dates set in that order and the amount owed became 
  the law of the case.Â  We agree.Â  
â€œAn unappealed order becomes 
  the law of the case. â€˜A portion of a judgment that is not appealed presents 
  no issue for determination by the reviewing court and constitutes, rightly or 
  wrongly, the law of the case.â€™â€Â  McCall v. State Farm Mut. Auto Ins. Co., 
  359 S.C. 372, 378, 597 S.E.2d 181, 184 (Ct. App. 2004) (citations omitted).
In this case, Franklin never 
  appealed from the masterâ€™s order on remand, which (1) held Franklin was liable 
  on interest that accrued, not only through August 29, 2002, but through the 
  date BB&T received written notice of the conclusion of any appeal from that 
  order, and (2) ordered Franklin to hold all rents from the property in trust 
  pending a further order or immediately pay over rents to BB&T for payment 
  of the principal, interest, and attorneyâ€™s fees due.Â  Because Franklin never 
  appealed from this order, Franklin is liable on the interest that accrued through 
  October 15, 2002, the date Franklin notified BB&T in writing that he abandoned 
  his appeal.Â  Moreover, Franklin was obligated by that order to hold all rents 
  in trust for payment of his liability.Â  The date that payment was made on the 
  mortgage was simply irrelevant in light of this order.Â Â  
Any argument Franklin had concerning 
  the date payment was made on the mortgage and its effect on the amount he owed 
  to BB&T in rents should have been raised on appeal from the order on remand.Â  
  Because Franklin did not appeal from the order on remand, it is the law of the 
  case.Â  See id.Â  Therefore, the master erred in ordering BB&T 
  to provide any information or witnesses concerning the mortgage payments and 
  disbursals. 
REVERSED. [3] 
 HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY 
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  Franklinâ€™s response does not appear in the record 
    on appeal.Â  

 
   
    [3]  We decline to address BB&Tâ€™s remaining issues on appeal.Â  See 
    Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 
    591, 598 (1999) (finding that an appellate court need not address remaining 
    issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Charles B. Byers,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Daniel  F.Â  Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-018
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate 
  Defense and Jeffrey P. Bloom, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Charles B. Byers appeals a 
  circuit courtâ€™s determination that his indictment sufficiently conferred subject 
  matter jurisdiction.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
In December 1999, Byers was convicted of murder 
  and sentenced to life imprisonment.Â  Subsequently, Byers appealed the conviction 
  to this Court.Â  In State v. Byers, 2002-UP-486 (Ct. App. 2002), we remanded 
  the case for an evidentiary hearing to determine whether the circuit court possessed 
  subject matter jurisdiction in light of the fact that the indictment in the 
  record did not indicate whether it was true billed.Â  
The remand hearing was held on December 12, 2002.Â  
  The circuit court considered a variety of evidence, including indictments, testimony 
  from Carla D. Hartley, grand jury foreperson at the time of the disputed indictment, 
  and Sharon Cato, an employee in the county clerk of courtâ€™s office.Â  
There are two indictments that are relevant to 
  the current appeal.Â  The First is signed by Hartley, and contains the notation 
  â€œtrueâ€ underneath the heading â€œVERDICT.â€Â  This indictment includes a 
  date of â€œ6/30/99.â€Â  The second indictment is also signed by Hartley, but underneath 
  â€œVERDICTâ€ the word â€œguiltyâ€ appears.Â  Beside â€œguiltyâ€ is the date â€œ12/8/99.â€Â  
  Below these entries is the signature of the petit jury foreperson.Â  The circuit 
  court noted that two copies of the indictment existed because the original indictment 
  was redacted to omit the word â€œtrueâ€ for petit jury use.Â  
Hartley testified she was not the regular grand jury 
  foreperson, but served in the absence of the previously appointed foreperson.Â  
  Although she did not have an independent recollection of Byersâ€™ indictment, 
  Hartley testified it was her signature and explained that during the grand jury 
  process, she wrote either â€œtrueâ€ or â€œnoâ€ on each indictment to signify whether 
  it was â€œtrue billedâ€ or â€œno billed.â€Â  Specifically, when questioned as to what 
  the word â€œtrueâ€ signified, Hartley responded that â€œ[i]t meant that the entire 
  grand jury had voted that this particular case was a true bill.â€
Hartley was also questioned about the role a bailiff 
  played in the grand jury proceedings.Â  She explained that when she got to court 
  and discovered she would be foreperson, â€œthe bailiff was the one that brought 
  me the information and told me what to . . . do and how to sign [the indictment].â€Â  
  Later, she clarified that after the bailiff told her how to proceed and sign 
  the documents, he left the room, did not reappear until the grand jury was finished 
  deliberating, and only returned to usher in the next law enforcement officer.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
Byers contends the circuit court erred in finding 
  the State carried its burden of proof in showing the indictment properly vested 
  the court with subject matter jurisdiction.Â  He further contends the grand jury 
  proceedings were improper because of irregularities involving the role of the 
  bailiff in those proceedings.Â  We disagree.
Typically, â€œa circuit court does not have subject 
  matter jurisdiction to hear a guilty plea unless the defendant has been indicted 
  by a grand jury or has waived presentment.â€Â  State v. Grim, 341 S.C. 
  63, 66, 533 S.E.2d 329, 330 (2000).Â  The lack of subject matter jurisdiction 
  may be raised at any time.Â  Id. at 66, 533 S.E.2d at 330.Â  In this case, 
  Byers did not waive presentment and he asserts irregularities in the indictment 
  process.Â  Proceedings in a court of general jurisdiction, however, will be presumed 
  regular absent evidence to the contrary.Â  Pringle v. State, 287 S.C. 
  409, 410-11, 339 S.E.2d 127, 128 (1986).
In Byers first appeal we were unable to determine 
  from the record if the indictments were properly true billed and accordingly, 
  we remanded the case to the trial court for that determination.Â  See 
  generally Anderson v. State, 338 S.C. 629, 633, 527 S.E.2d 398, 
  400 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œIt is appropriate to remand to the trial court for a determination 
  when there is not sufficient evidence for the court to determine if the indictment 
  was true billed.â€).Â  The trial court heard evidence from the jury foreperson 
  and determined the indictment was properly true billed.Â  Byers argues the trial 
  court erred in ruling the State carried its burden of proof, and that such burden 
  is by clear and convincing evidence.
Multiple South Carolina cases have been remanded 
  for a determination of whether an indictment was true billed, yet none of these 
  has enunciated the burden of proof the State is required to meet.Â  Byers asserts 
  the burden is by clear and convincing evidence and that this standard is supported 
  by language from Grim that â€œcaution must be exercised to ensure the presence 
  of subject matter jurisdiction.â€Â  Grim, 341 S.C. at 66, 533 S.E.2d at 
  330.Â  The State, on the other hand, urges the court to adopt a preponderance 
  of the evidence standard.Â  Because it is unnecessary to our decision in this 
  case, we decline to adopt any specific standard as the evidence in this case 
  fulfills either.
In Pringle, an indictment was stamped â€œtrue 
  bill,â€ but did not contain the forepersonâ€™s signature.Â  Pringle, 287 
  S.C. at 410, 339 S.E.2d at 128.Â  The court pointed to testimony by the foreperson 
  that rather than signing the indictment, the usual procedure was to have the 
  clerk publish the indictment in open court after the grand jury returned a true 
  billed indictment.Â  Id. at 411, 339 S.E.2d 128.Â  The court determined 
  the forepersonâ€™s signature was not essential to the validity of an indictment.Â  
  Id. at 410, 339 S.E.2d 128.
Anderson  involved an indictment that did 
  not contain the term â€œtrue bill.â€Â  Anderson, 338 S.C. at 632, 527 S.E.2d 
  at 399.Â  The court remanded the case to determine if subject matter jurisdiction 
  existed because no evidence demonstrated that the indictment was true billed.Â Â  
  Id. at 633, 527 S.E.2d 400.Â  
Unlike Anderson, the record in Bultron, 
  contained extensive evidence that the grand jury true billed an indictment that 
  was not otherwise marked as true billed.Â  Id. at 328, 457 S.E.2d at 619.Â  
  The record contained testimony from the county docket coordinator that during 
  the term containing the Bultron indictment, the grand jury true billed 
  every proposed indictment.Â  Id. at 329, 457 S.E.2d at 619-20.Â  This testimony 
  was corroborated by the testimony of the court reporter present when the findings 
  of the grand jury were announced and a legal secretary for the county.Â  Id.
This case is factually similar to Bultron, 
  in that there is uncontroverted testimony by an individual involved in the process 
  that this indictment was true billed.Â  This testimony comes from the actual 
  grand jury foreperson, who testified that the indictment was signed by her, 
  marked â€œtrueâ€ by her, and that by marking â€œtrue,â€ she signified the indictment 
  was true billed.Â  This evidence proves by either standard that this indictment 
  was properly true billed.
During the hearing on remand, there was also testimony 
  that the bailiff provided directions to the grand jury foreperson.Â  Byers argues 
  such direction constitutes active participation by the bailiff in the grand 
  jury process, and that advice to the grand jury should only come from a judicial 
  official.Â  After a thorough review of the record, we find the bailiffâ€™s directions 
  were administrative in nature and made necessary by the fact the normal grand 
  jury foreperson was absent.Â  The directions were given within the first few 
  minutes of the jury coming together and the foreperson made it clear in her 
  testimony that the bailiff was never a part of deliberations.Â  We find these 
  actions to have caused no prejudice.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, 
  the circuit courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS,
JJ., concur.

 
   
     
    [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215,
  SCACR.

title: Currow v. Glaze
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Marion Ann Currow, Personal Representative For The Estate Of James Marion 
        Glaze, Appellant,
v.
Evelyn M. Glaze, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â FrancesÂ  P. Segars-Andrews, Family 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-019
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Cynthia Barrier Castengera, of Newland and David Dusty Rhoades, of Charleston, 
  for Appellant.
Evelyn M. Glaze, of Charleston, Pro Se Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Marion Ann Currow, as Personal Representative for the Estate 
  of James Marion Glaze (Husband), appeals the decision of the family court reaffirming 
  its order that Husband maintain life insurance on his ex-wife, Evelyn M. Glaze 
  (Wife), as security for alimony.Â  We affirm. [1] Â  
FACTS
This domestic relations action was originally heard before the family court 
  in 2001.Â  The family courtâ€™s 2001 order, among other things, granted the parties 
  a divorce, awarded alimony to the Wife, andÂ  required Husband to maintain a 
  life insurance policy naming Wife as the beneficiary.Â Â  Husband appealed, and 
  this Court, in Unpublished Opinion No. 2003-UP-258 (filed April 8, 2003), remanded 
  the case to the family court.Â  We held the court failed to indicate the basis 
  for its requirement that husband maintain a life insurance policy naming Wife 
  as the beneficiary. Â Further, the family court had failed to consider the statutory 
  factors for ordering life insurance as security for alimony.
Accordingly, in September of 2003, the family court issued an order from the 
  hearing on remand, addressing the statutory factors.Â  The court reaffirmed its 
  2001 order establishing security for alimony in the form of life insurance.Â  
  Subsequently, in October of 2003, Wooten v. Wooten, 356 S.C. 473, 589 
  S.E.2d 769 (Ct. App. 2003) cert. granted June 24, 2004, was published.Â  
  Wooten established that â€œa compelling reason must exist to warrant the 
  maintenance of life insurance by the supporting spouse.â€Â  356 S.C. at 476, 589 
  S.E.2d at 770-71 (internal quotation marks omitted).Â  The Wooten court 
  further ruled the sole fact that a former spouse would benefit financially from 
  life insurance in the event of the payorâ€™s death did notÂ  establish a compelling 
  reason for requiring life insurance as security for alimony.Â  Id. at 
  478, 589 S.E.2d at 771-72.Â  Based on the intervening release of Wooten, 
  Husband filed a Rule 59(e) motion, which was denied.Â  He now appeals, contending 
  the family court on remand erred in its analysis and application of the statutory 
  factors set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(D) (Supp 2003). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Analysis of Â§ 20-3-130(D)
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(D) (Supp. 2003) provides:

In making an award of alimony or separate maintenance and support, 
  the court may make provision for security for the payment of the support including, 
  but not limited to, requiring the posting of money, property, and bonds and 
  may require a spouse, with due consideration of [1] the cost of premiums, 
  [2] insurance plans carried by the parties during marriage, [3] insurability 
  of the payor spouse, [4] the probable economic condition of the supported 
  spouse upon the death of the payor spouse, and [5] any other factors 
  the court may deem relevant, to carry and maintain life insurance so as to assure 
  support of a spouse beyond the death of the payor spouse.

(Alterations added).Â  
On remand, the family court examined each of these factors.Â  The first factor 
  is the cost of premiums.Â  The court found that Husband, who by that time was 
  deceased, had carried the policy in question for years.Â  The court opined that 
  the premiums up until his death â€œwere not considerable nor were they a new expense 
  related to the issuance of this courtâ€™s order.â€Â  
The second factor looks to insurance plans carried by the parties during marriage.Â  
  The court noted that the Husband carried the policy in question during the marriage, 
  and therefore, it was not a new burden.Â  
The third factor, that of insurability of the payor spouse, â€œwas questionable 
  as both the [Husband] and the [Wife] were in demonstrably poor health.â€Â  However, 
  because the policy was already in place, the insurability of the payor spouse 
  was not an issue.Â  
The fourth factor is the probable economic condition of the supported spouse 
  upon the death of the payor spouse.Â  The record reveals that both Husband and 
  Wife were in poor economic condition.Â  Unfortunately, Husband died; it was found 
  that the economic condition of the Wife upon Husbandâ€™s death was poor.Â  
Finally, the statute provides that the court consider any other factors which 
  the court deems may be relevant.Â  Here, the family court found that the alimony 
  awarded to Wife would have been a nullity without the insurance policy as appropriate 
  security.Â  
As instructed, the family court examined the factors established 
  by our legislature and codified in Â§ 20-3-130(D).Â  We find no abuse of discretion.Â  

II.Â Â Â Â Â  Compelling Reason Standard/Wooten
Husband contends that Wooten requires reversal of the family 
  court.Â  We disagree.Â  In its November 2003 order denying Husbandâ€™s Rule 59(e) 
  motion, the court acknowledged that it had â€œspecifically considered the case 
  of Wooten v. Wooten.â€Â  The citation of Wooten v. Wooten in the 
  Rule 59(e) order clearly reveals that the family court judge undertook an analysis 
  of Wooten concerning the compelling reasons test.Â  Based on the economic 
  considerations and the age of the parties as discussed by the family court in 
  connection with its analysis of Â§ 20-3-130(D), we conclude there was a sufficiently 
  compelling reason to require security for alimony in this case.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the 
  family court is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
