title: State v. Davis
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT 
  BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Tony Davis, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-021
Heard December 8, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Acting Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, Office of Appellate Defense, of 
  Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. 
  McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
Senior Assistant Attorney General Mark Rapoport, Office of the Attorney General; 
  and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Tony Davis appeals his armed 
  robbery conviction asserting the trial judge erred in (1) failing to charge 
  the jury on the lesser-included offense of common law robbery where the evidence 
  showed he only had a BB gun during the commission of the crime and (2) sentencing 
  him to life without the possibility of parole when the prior armed robbery relied 
  on for sentencing was not final as it was a guilty plea for which he had not 
  yet been sentenced.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On June 29, 
  2000, Bi-Lo employee Robena Young became suspicious of a male customer who continuously 
  walked up and down the same aisle with a buggy, watching her and watching the 
  front office.Â  Robena then alerted employee Mary Baughman, and Mary then walked 
  to the scanner room to tell employee Jennifer McCollum.Â  As Mary stepped in 
  the scanner room and began to relay the information to Jennifer, the man came 
  behind Mary into the room, pretending to look behind the door to the scanner 
  room.Â  When Jennifer asked what the man wanted, he closed the door, pulled up 
  his jacket, and pulled out a gun.Â  The man pointed the gun at both women 
  and ordered them to the ground. Â Robena realized there was a robbery in progress 
  and alerted supervisor Robert Taylor.Â  Taylor went to the scanner room and knocked 
  on the door.Â  Upon hearing the knock, the man instructed the two women to stand 
  and pretend as if nothing happened.Â  The man then opened the door and attempted 
  to pull Robert into the room.Â  Robert and the man struggled, but Robert began 
  to comply because the man put the gun in Robertâ€™s side.Â  Just as Robert stepped 
  in the scanner room, the bookkeeper, Penny, opened the door to the cash office.Â  
  In an attempt to get away from the man, Jennifer pushed Penny back into the 
  cash office, but the man followed Jennifer in there.Â  The man opened up the 
  cash drawer, grabbed a big handful of money, and fled from the store.Â  
A few months later, Investigator Vinson showed the witnesses a photographic 
  line-up that included Davisâ€™ picture.Â  Mary indicated Davis â€œcould beâ€ the man 
  who robbed the store that day.Â  Jennifer and Robena both picked Davisâ€™ picture 
  without hesitation.Â  Davis was thereafter arrested and indicted for armed robbery.Â  
  Following a jury trial, Davis was convicted as charged and the trial judge sentenced 
  him to life in prison without the possibility of parole.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Lesser Included Offense
Davis first contends the trial judge erred in refusing to charge the jury 
  on the law of common law robbery because the evidence showed he used a BB gun 
  in the robbery.Â  We disagree.
During the trial, the parties stipulated that Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 16, a BB 
  gun, was found in Davisâ€™ possession in September 2000.Â  Jennifer McCollum testified 
  Exhibit No. 16 resembled the weapon used by the man who robbed the store.Â  Investigator 
  Vinson testified Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 16 was a â€œCrossman BB gunâ€ made to look 
  like a â€œgovernment model 45.â€Â  At the close of the evidence, defense counsel 
  requested a charge on the lesser-included offense of strong armed robbery, asserting 
  whether or not the witnesses reasonably believed the BB gun was a deadly weapon 
  was a matter for the jury.Â  The trial judge determined the lesser-included offense 
  should not be presented to the jury under the facts of this case.Â  Thereafter, 
  the court instructed the jury on the law of armed robbery and submitted two 
  verdict forms:Â  guilty of armed robbery and not guilty. 
  [1] Â  
A trial court must determine the law to be charged based on the evidence presented 
  at trial.Â  State v. Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 51, 584 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2003).Â  
  The presence of evidence to sustain a conviction for the crime of a lesser degree 
  determines whether such a charge should be submitted to the jury.Â  State 
  v. Atkins, 293 S.C. 294, 298, 360 S.E.2d 302, 305 (1987) overruled on 
  other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).Â  
  Due process requires a lesser-included offense be charged to the jury only when 
  there is evidence from which it could be inferred that the defendant committed 
  the lesser rather than the greater offense.Â  Id.; State v. Murphy, 
  322 S.C. 321, 325, 471 S.E.2d 739, 741 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œ[W]here there is no 
  evidence to support a finding that the defendant was guilty of the lesser offense, 
  there can be no error in the failure to charge the lesser offense.â€Â  State 
  v. Gadsden, 314 S.C. 229, 232, 442 S.E.2d 594, 597 (1994).Â  Concomitantly, 
  where there is no evidence to support a jury instruction on a lesser-included 
  offense, a jury charge which effectively prohibits the jury from considering 
  the lesser-included offense cannot be error.Â  Id.  
Common law robbery is defined as the felonious or unlawful taking of money, 
  goods, or other personal property of any value from the person of another or 
  in his presence by violence or by putting such person in fear.Â  State v. 
  Drayton, 293 S.C. 417, 428, 361 S.E.2d 329, 335 (1987).Â  Armed robbery occurs 
  when one commits a robbery and either:Â  (1) he is armed with a deadly weapon 
  or (2) he alleges he is armed with a deadly weapon, either by action or words, 
  while using a representation of a deadly weapon or any object which a person 
  present during the commission of the robbery reasonably believes to be a deadly 
  weapon.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330(A) (2003);Â  State v. Muldrow, 348 
  S.C. 264, 267-68, 559 S.E.2d 847, 849 (2002).
The only evidence presented at trial indicates the perpetrator was 
  either armed with a deadly weapon [2] , or alleged he was armed with a deadly weapon 
  by action â€œwhile using a representation of a deadly weapon or any object which 
  a person present during the commission of the robbery reasonably believed to 
  be a deadly weapon.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330 (2003). Â Mary Baughman testified 
  the perpetrator of the crime pointed â€œa large black pistolâ€ at her.Â  Robert 
  Taylor stated the gun used was a handgun, and that it was â€œlike a black gun 
  that an officer would carry.â€Â  He further testified that the gun â€œlooked real 
  to me.â€Â  Jennifer McCollum indicated the robber used a big, black handgun.Â  
  When defense counsel asked Jennifer whether she understood Stateâ€™s Exhibit No. 
  16 was a BB gun she replied, â€œNo, Sir.â€Â  She testified she saw an object that 
  she believed to be an actual handgun, as opposed to a BB gun.Â  Thus, while the 
  question of whether a BB gun is a deadly weapon may be an issue for the jury, 
  the facts of this case show only that the robber alleged he was armed with a 
  deadly weapon by using a representation of a deadly weapon which the victims 
  reasonably believed to be a deadly weapon.Â  In other words, while there may 
  be a jury issue as to the first prong of Â§ 16-11-330, there is no jury issue 
  as to the second prong.Â  There simply is no evidence that Davis was guilty of 
  the lesser-included offense of common law robbery.Â  
II. Sentencing
Davis also argues the trial judge erred in sentencing him 
  to life without parole based on a prior guilty plea to armed robbery Davis had 
  entered but for which he had not yet been sentenced.Â  He asserts the lack of 
  sentencing prevented the guilty plea from being a final conviction such that 
  the trial judge could not consider it as a prior offense for sentencing purposes.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
â€œIn the interpretation of statutes, our sole function is 
  to determine and, within constitutional limits, give effect to the intention 
  of the legislature, with reference to the meaning of the language used and the 
  subject matter and purpose of the statute.â€Â  State v. Ramsey, 311 S.C. 
  555, 561, 430 S.E.2d 511, 515 (1993).Â  â€œIn construing a statute, words must 
  be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced 
  construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.â€Â  Id.Â  A statute 
  is construed â€œby determining its meaning from the language used and its subject 
  matter and purposes.â€Â  State v. Carrigan, 284 S.C. 610, 617, 328 S.E.2d 
  119, 123 (Ct. App. 1985). Â If a statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous 
  and it conveys a clear and definite meaning, there is no need to employ rules 
  of statutory interpretation.Â  State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 359, 366-67, 
  574 S.E.2d 203, 206-207 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Further, when the terms of a statute 
  are clear, the court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.Â  
  Id.Â  at 367, 574 S.E.2d at 207.Â  
Section 17-25-45 of the South Carolina Code requires â€œupon a conviction 
  for a most serious offense as defined by this section, a person must be sentenced 
  to a term of imprisonment for life without the possibility of parole if that 
  person has one or more prior convictions for:Â  (1) a most serious offense.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(A)(1) (2003).Â  It defines â€œmost serious offenseâ€ as 
  including armed robbery.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(C)(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  It 
  defines prior conviction as meaning â€œthe defendant has been convicted of a most 
  serious or serious offense, as may be applicable, on a separate occasion, prior 
  to the instant adjudication.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(F) (2003).Â  Finally, 
  it explicitly defines conviction as â€œany conviction, guilty plea, or 
  plea of nolo contendere.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(C)(3) (2003) (emphasis 
  added).Â  The plain meaning of the statute clearly indicates the trial court 
  correctly considered Davisâ€™s guilty plea when making its sentencing determination.Â  

Further, the legislative intent is clear from the history of Â§ 17-25-45.Â  Prior 
  to January 1, 1996, this code section provided, â€œfor the purpose of this section 
  only, a conviction is considered a second conviction only if the date of the 
  commission of the second crime occurred subsequent to the imposition of the 
  sentence for the first offense.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(B) (Supp. 1995) 
  (emphasis added).Â  The statute was amended in 1995 to delete the provision regarding 
  the imposition of sentence, and added the provision defining â€œconvictionâ€ to 
  include a guilty plea.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45 (Supp. 1995).
Accordingly, both the plain meaning of the statute and the legislative 
  intent clearly show the trial judge properly considered Davisâ€™ prior guilty 
  plea to armed robbery as a prior conviction of a most serious offense for purposes 
  of sentencing.
CONCLUSION
Because there was no 
  evidence to support a finding that Davis was guilty of the lesser offense of 
  common law robbery, we hold there was no error in the jury charge which effectively 
  prohibited the jury from considering the lesser-included offense.Â  We further 
  hold the trial court properly considered Davisâ€™ prior guilty plea to armed robbery 
  in sentencing Davis to life without parole pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45.Â  
  Therefore, the order of the trial court is 
 AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, 
  and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] While Davis couches his arguments in terms of the trial judgeâ€™s 
    failure to charge the jury on the lesser-included offense of common law robbery, 
    it should be noted the trial judge did in fact charge the law of common law 
    robbery in conjunction with charging the jury the law on armed robbery.Â  It 
    is clear, however, the trial judge refused to submit the charge of common 
    law robbery for the juryâ€™s consideration.Â  

 
   [2] SeeÂ  State v. Heck, 304 S.C. 345, 404 S.E.2d 514 
    (Ct. App. 1991), cert. denied, 502 U.S. 1043, 112 S.Ct. 900, 
    116 L.Ed.2d 802 (1992) (wherein this court found a BB gun to be a weapon capable 
    of producing great bodily harm such that it qualified as a deadly weapon and 
    was properly submitted as a factual determination for the jury for purposes 
    of an armed robbery charge).Â

title: BB&T v. Simpson
text:
PER CURIAM:


THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ex Parte:
Christine A. Dunagin, Respondent,
In Re:
BB&T Bankcard Corporation, Appellant,
v.
Mike Simpson, Jr. and Eula L. Simpson, Defendants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-022
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John William Ray, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Rodney Wade Richey, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  




PER CURIAM:Â  BB&T Bankcard Corporation 
  (BB&T) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s denial of its motion for attorneyâ€™s fees 
  and costs against Christine A. Dunagin pursuant to Rule 11, SCRCP.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
BB&T brought a breach of contract 
  action against Mike and Eula Simpson after the Simpsons defaulted on their credit 
  card agreement.Â  The Simpsons, through their counsel, Dunagin, responded with 
  a general denial, and further stated they had retained counsel for the purpose 
  of filing bankruptcy, â€œin which this matter will be dealt with.â€Â  BB&T moved 
  for summary judgment or in the alternative to strike claiming the answer was 
  filed for delay and violated SCRCP 11(a).Â  BB&T also proceeded with discovery 
  and served interrogatories on the Simpsons.  
Dunagin wrote BB&Tâ€™s 
  counsel, acknowledging receipt of discovery requests and informing him â€œit is 
  estimated that the Simpsons will be filing for Chapter 13 bankruptcy protection 
  within 1 to 2 weeks, therefore, we will not be responding to the discovery requests.â€Â  
  Counsel responded by noticing the Simpsonsâ€™ depositions.Â  Three days prior to 
  the scheduled depositions, Dunagin again wrote to BB&Tâ€™s counsel informing 
  him the Simpsons had filed a bankruptcy petition under Chapter 13, thereby staying 
  BB&Tâ€™s action against them.Â  Counsel filed a motion for sanctions pursuant 
  to Rule 11, SCRCP, claiming the Simpsonsâ€™ answer â€œwas filed and served in bad 
  faith and purely for delay, and the Plaintiff is entitled to an award of fees 
  and costs from attorney Dunagin as a matter of law.â€ Â Following a hearing, 
  the trial court denied the motion for sanctions in a form order without assigning 
  specific reasons for the denial.Â  
DISCUSSION
BB&T argues the trial court 
  erred in denying its motion for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to Rule 11, 
  SCRCP.Â  We disagree.
The criteria for awarding sanctions 
  pursuant to Rule 11 are essentially the same as those for sanctions under the 
  Frivolous Civil Proceedings Act.Â  Father v. SCDSS, 353 S.C. 254, 262, 
  578 S.E.2d 11, 15 (2003).Â  The decision whether to impose sanctions under the 
  FCPSA sounds in equity rather than at law.Â  Id. at 260, 578 S.E.2d at 
  14.Â  In such an action, an appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in 
  accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  S. C. Const. 
  Art. V, Â§ 5; see also Townes Assocs. Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 
  266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  However, following a determination 
  of the facts, an appellate court applies an abuse of discretion standard in 
  reviewing the decision to award sanctions and the specific sanctions awarded.Â  
  Father, 353 S.C. at 261, 578 S.E.2d at 14.Â  
Rule 11(a), SCRCP provides in 
  part:

The signature of an attorney or party [on a pleading, motion or other paper] 
  constitutes a certificate by him that he has read the pleading, motion or other 
  paper; and that to the best of his knowledge, information and belief there is 
  good ground to support it; and that it is not interposed for delay.

Under the rule, the court may sanction an attorney 
  for filing a pleading in bad faith (i.e., to cause unnecessary delay) irrespective 
  of whether there is good ground to support it.Â  Runyon v. Wright, 322 
  S.C. 15, 19, 471 S.E.2d 160, 162 (1996).Â  The sanction may include an order 
  to pay the reasonable costs and attorneyâ€™s fees incurred by the party or parties 
  defending against the action brought in bad faith.Â  Id.; Rule 11(a)
SCRCP.  

Here, BB&T argues the â€œsole 
  purpose of the Answer was to detain and impair the authority of the lower court 
  and to delay and generate further injury to the opposing party.â€Â  As evidence 
  of bad faith, BB&T points to Dunaginâ€™s general denial of the allegations 
  contained in its complaint, and her later decision not to respond to discovery 
  requests.Â  
The circuit court did not make 
  specific findings of fact or rule on BB&Tâ€™s allegations of bad faith in 
  filing the answer. The courtâ€™s order simply stated, â€œPlaintiffâ€™s Motion for 
  Sanctions is DENIED.â€Â  The record does not indicate and BB&T does 
  not contend it filed a 59(e) motion asking the court to provide the factual 
  basis for its ruling or address BB&Tâ€™s allegations of bad faith.Â  
However, the Simpsonsâ€™ answer clearly disclosed 
  their intention to file for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 13.Â  Dunaginâ€™s 
  later correspondence with BB&T explained the decision not to respond to 
  discovery requests was in anticipation of the Simpsonsâ€™ petitioning for bankruptcy.Â  
  We hold these facts support the courtâ€™s conclusion that Dunagin did not engage 
  in sanctionable behavior in this case.Â  The record reveals her willingness to 
  disclose, at the first opportunity, the intention of her clients to seek bankruptcy 
  protection.Â  Consequently, after carefully reviewing the factual circumstances, 
  we hold the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in denying BB&Tâ€™s 
  motion for sanctions pursuant to Rule 11, SCRCP.Â  
AFFIRMED.Â  
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., 
  concur.Â 

 
   
    [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM:Â  Benjamin Cantrell appeals the circuit courtâ€™s 
  order affirming the administrative hearing officerâ€™s decision that his arrest 
  for driving under the influence was lawful.Â  We affirm 
  [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  

As to the lawfulness of Cantrellâ€™s arrest in a parking garage:Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2930 (Supp. 2003) (â€œIt is unlawful for a person to drive a 
  motor vehicle within this State while:Â  (1) under the influence of alcohol

As to an alleged violation of the videotaping requirement pursuant 
  to S.C. Code Ann. section 56-5-2953 (Supp. 2003), the absence of counsel for 
  the State at the appellate hearing before the circuit court, and the circuit 
  courtâ€™s alleged failure to consider error by the administrative hearing officer 
  and the arresting officer:Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497

 AFFIRMED.

    215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

v.
Parton Land & Timber Company, Inc., and Custom Grading & Construction, 
        Inc., d/b/a Carolina Earth Movers, Defendants,
of Whom Parton Land & Timber Company, Inc. is,
Appellant.

John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-024
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

Douglas F. Gay, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.Â  
Lucy London McDow, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Parton Land & Timber Company, Inc. appeals the juryâ€™s 
  award of punitive damages to David Kaveh on his claim for conversion of timber 
  arguing the court erred by denying its motions for judgment notwithstanding 
  the verdict or, in the alternative, for a new trial absolute.Â  We affirm [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:
As to the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion for judgment notwithstanding 
  the verdict:Â  Rule 50(b), SCRCP (â€œA party who has moved for a directed verdict 
  may move to have the verdict and any judgment entered thereon set aside and 
  to have judgment entered in accordance with his motion for a directed verdict[.]â€) 
  (emphasis added); Johnson v. Hoechst Celanese Corp., 317 S.C. 415, 420, 
  453 S.E.2d 908, 911 (Ct. App. 1995) (â€œIf a party fails to make a directed verdict 
  motion before the jury retires, the party cannot subsequently move for JNOV.â€).
As to the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion for new trial absolute:Â  
  Vick v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 347 S.C. 470, 481, 556 S.E.2d 
  693, 699 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe juryâ€™s determination of damages is entitled to 
  substantial deference.â€); Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 379-80, 426 
  S.E.2d 802, 805 (1993) (â€œThe trial court should grant a new trial based on the 
  excessiveness of the verdict only if the amount is not merely different from 
  that which he would have awarded, but is so grossly excessive so as to shock 
  the conscience of the court and clearly indicates that the figure reached was 
  the result of caprice, passion, prejudice, partiality, corruption or other improper 
  motives.â€); Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 404, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723 
  (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œThe grant or denial of new trial motions rests within the 
  discretion of the trial judge and his decision will not be disturbed on appeal 
  unless his findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions 
  reached are controlled by error of law.â€); McGee v. Bruce Hosp. Sys., 
  321 S.C. 340, 346, 468 S.E.2d 633, 637 (1996) (holding an appellantâ€™s allegations 
  of error by the trial court in reviewing an award of punitive damages pursuant 
  to Gamble v. Stevenson, 305 S.C. 104, 406 S.E.2d 350 (1991) are unpreserved 
  where the issue was not raised to the trial court).Â  
 AFFIRMED. 
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

title: Hill v. CP&L
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Larry Hill and Juliette Hill d/b/a Profile Enterprises,
Appellants,
v.
      The City of Sumter, Carolina Power and Light Company, Time Warner Entertainment 
        Company, C.B. Askins and Company and Kenneth Simmons Associates, Defendants,
      of whom Carolina Power and Light Company is, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-025
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  13, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Garryl L. Deas, of Sumter, for Appellants.
Hugh L. Willcox, Jr. and Marian H. Lee, both of Florence, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action for trespass and negligence, Larry and Juliette 
  Hill appeal the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Carolina Power and 
  Light Company (CP&L).Â  We affirm. [1] Â  
BACKGROUND
The Hills own 
  a building in downtown Sumter in which they operate a beauty salon.Â  The property 
  was in the area of the City of Sumterâ€™s renovation project, which as to the 
  Hills involved replacing a wall on their property and relocating electrical 
  equipment from overhead to underground.Â  CP&L provided, and continues to 
  provide, electrical service to the Hills and was directly involved with the 
  Cityâ€™s renovation project.Â  
According to the Hills, 
  they did not consent to the installation of underground wiring or the placement 
  of transformers on their property by CP&L.Â  Larry Hill said he told CP&L 
  employees to stop digging on his property.Â  However, a CP&L employee, Joe 
  Bailey, attested Juliette Hill consented to placing two transformers and underground 
  wiring on her property.Â  Also, according to CP&L, Larry Hill contacted the 
  company and revoked consent as to the transformers but not the underground lines.Â  

Ultimately, CP&L 
  placed the two transformers on adjacent property and the lines underground. 
  Â The underground lines provide electricity to the Hillsâ€™ building and an underground 
  junction box at the back of their building provides service to the adjacent 
  property owner.Â  Essentially, CP&L merely placed underground the formerly 
  above-ground service and did so pursuant to its service regulations.Â  
The Hills filed suit against the City of Sumter, CP&L, and other 
  renovation project partners.Â  The Hills alleged negligence and trespass, and, 
  as to the City, they also alleged inverse condemnation.Â  The trial court granted 
  summary judgment to CP&L and partial summary judgment to the City on any 
  causes of action stemming from the â€œinstallation of the underground services 
  by CP&L.â€Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Hills argue the trial court erred in granting 
  summary judgment to CP&L.Â  We disagree.
Summary judgment is appropriate when no genuine issue of 
  material fact exists and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter 
  of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, the 
  evidence and reasonable inferences drawn therefrom should be viewed in a light 
  most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 
  69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 439 (2003).Â  In reviewing the grant of summary judgment, 
  the appellate court applies the same standard as the trial court under Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  Id. at 69, 580 S.E.2d at 438-39.Â Â  
I.Â  Trespass
To support their trespass cause of action, the Hills 
  use the laws of inverse condemnation to suggest CP&Lâ€™s actions constituted 
  a taking.Â  In other words, they argue that because it did not institute an action 
  under the Eminent Domain Procedures Act, CP&L lacked permission and authority 
  to be on their property, and thus trespassed.Â  
Trespass is any interference with the property ownerâ€™s 
  right to the â€œexclusive, peaceable possession of his property.â€Â  Ravan v. 
  Greenville County, 315 S.C. 447, 463, 434 S.E.2d 296, 306 (Ct. App. 1993) 
  (citations omitted).Â  â€œThe essence of trespass is the unauthorized entry onto 
  the land of another.â€Â  Id. at 464, 434 S.E.2d at 306 (citations omitted).Â  
  â€œTo constitute an actionable trespass, the act must be affirmative, the invasion 
  of the land must be intentional, and the harm caused by the invasion of the 
  land must be the direct result of that invasion.â€Â  Mack v. Edens, 320 
  S.C. 236, 240, 464 S.E.2d 124, 127 (Ct. App. 1995).
The Hills are customers of CP&L.Â  CP&Lâ€™s service 
  regulations explicitly authorize its entry onto the Hillsâ€™ land.Â  The following 
  is stated in paragraph 2(a) of the regulations:

Company is not obligated to supply electricity to customer 
  unless and until: . . . in cases where it is necessary to cross private property 
  to deliver electricity to Customer, Customer conveys or causes to be conveyed 
  to Company, without cost to Company, a right of way easement, satisfactory to 
  Company, across such private property for the construction, maintenance, and 
  operation of Companyâ€™s lines and facilities, necessary to the delivery of electricity 
  by Company to Customer: provided, however, in the absence of a formal conveyance, 
  Company, nevertheless, shall be vested with an easement over Customerâ€™s premises 
  authorizing it to do all things necessary to the construction, maintenance, 
  and operation of its lines and facilities for such purpose.[ 
  [2] ]Â  

The Hills assert 
  these service regulations do not supersede the laws of inverse condemnation.Â  
  CP&L does not assert it is exempt from the laws of condemnation and inverse 
  condemnation.Â  Rather, it says the service regulations allow it to access its 
  customersâ€™ property to provide service and this permissive access defeats a 
  claim of trespass.Â  We agree.Â  Because CP&L was authorized to be on the 
  Hillsâ€™ property, no trespass could have occurred.Â  
II.Â  Negligence
The Hills also 
  argue their negligence claim against CP&L should have survived summary judgment.Â  
  The Hills allege CP&L negligently placed the junction box, preventing them 
  from expanding their building and assert their affidavits were sufficient to 
  create a genuine issue of material fact.Â  Yet, in their affidavits, the Hills 
  fail to allege any negligent act on the part of CP&L or demand CP&L 
  move the junction box to allow them to expand their property.Â  Instead, the 
  Hills allege in their affidavits merely that they did not consent to CP&Lâ€™s 
  actions.Â  Moreover, CP&L has offered to move the junction box should the 
  Hills desire to expand.Â  Because there is an absence of a genuine issue of material 
  fact as to the negligence claim, the court properly granted summary judgment 
  to CP&L.
AFFIRMED.
 ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR. Â Â Â Â Â Â  

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Public Service Commission approved CP&Lâ€™s service 
    regulations on April 5, 1995 by Order Number 95-837.Â  The regulations also 
    provide that facilities installed for service of a customer may be used to 
    supply service to others.Â

title: Keels v. Poston
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ida Mae Keels, Respondent,
v.
William Poston, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-039
Submitted October 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David Craig Brown, of Florence, and Robert J. Thomas, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.Â  
Charles D. Barr, of Kingstree, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  William Poston appeals 
  the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motions for directed verdict, judgment notwithstanding 
  the verdict, and new trial.Â  Poston also challenges the admission of certain 
  evidence and testimony.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
In her complaint, Ida Mae Keels 
  alleged Poston was negligent by failing to yield the right of way and failing 
  to keep a proper lookout after the parties were involved in a minor traffic 
  accident at an intersection in downtown Kingstree, South Carolina.Â  Keels claimed 
  she suffered permanent injury to her neck and shoulder and requested damages 
  of $50,000.Â  Poston denied Keelsâ€™ allegations and pled a comparative negligence 
  defense.Â  
Keels was traveling eastbound across Mills 
  Street and Poston was driving north on Hampton when Poston struck the right 
  rear bumper of Keelsâ€™ car as she crossed the intersection.Â  The police officer 
  responding to the accident testified both vehicles were traveling at a speed 
  of between ten and twenty-five miles per hour, and damage to Keelsâ€™ car was 
  minimal.Â  The officer testified there was a stop sign posted on Mills Street 
  leading into the intersection, but not on Hampton Street.Â  
Keels testified she obeyed the 
  stop sign, looked both ways, and then pulled up beyond the stop sign to make 
  sure the intersection was clear before proceeding.Â  Poston testified he was 
  driving slowly on Hampton Street, and when he neared the intersection he suddenly 
  saw a car coming across in front of him from the left.Â  He stated he tried to 
  stop, but could not avoid hitting Keelsâ€™ car.Â  
Poston made timely motions for 
  directed verdict, arguing Keels had failed to present any evidence of his negligence.Â  
  Although the trial court acknowledged the evidence supporting Postonâ€™s negligence 
  was thin and expressed concern there was no testimony about how Poston was driving, 
  Postonâ€™s motions were denied and the court permitted the case to go to the jury 
  on the question of comparative negligence.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The jury found Poston 
  100% liable for the accident and awarded Keels $35,000 in damages.Â  The trial 
  court denied Postonâ€™s motions for judgment notwithstanding the verdict and a 
  new trial.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Motions for Directed Verdict, JNOV, and New Trial
Poston contends the trial court 
  erred by denying his motions for directed verdict and JNOV, arguing Keels failed 
  to present any evidence to support a finding he was negligent.Â  We disagree.
When ruling on directed verdict 
  or JNOV motions, the trial court must view the evidence and the inferences that 
  may reasonably be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving 
  party.Â  Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567, S.E.2d 
  231, 236 (2002).Â  If the evidence as a whole is susceptible to more than one 
  reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should be denied.Â  
  Bailey v. Segars, 346 S.C. 359, 365-66, 550 S.E.2d 910, 913 (Ct. App. 
  2001).Â  This court will not reverse the denial of a motion for directed verdict 
  unless there is no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  South Carolina 
  Prop. & Cas. Guar. Assâ€™n v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 521, 548 S.E.2d 880, 
  885 (Ct. App. 2001).
Poston testified he did not see 
  Keelsâ€™ car until immediately before he struck her vehicle.Â  The jury could have 
  reasonably inferred from his testimony and from the location of the damage to 
  Keelsâ€™ car that Poston failed to keep a proper lookout before motoring through 
  the intersection and, as a result of his negligence, proximately caused the 
  accident.Â  See Cope v. Eckert, 284 S.C. 516, 519, 327 S.E.2d 367, 
  369 (Ct. App. 1985) (stating South Carolina recognizes a duty of care in keeping 
  a proper lookout for travelers on favored and unfavored roads); see also 
  Brown v. Howell, 284 S.C. 605, 609, 327 S.E.2d 659, 661 (Ct. App. 1985) 
  (affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of plaintiffâ€™s motion for directed verdict 
  finding â€œthe jury could also reasonably infer from the evidence that [the plaintiff] 
  did not exercise due care for his own safety in that he failed to keep a proper 
  lookoutâ€).
Additionally, Keels testified 
  she stopped at the stop sign on Mills Street, looked both ways, and then pulled 
  up a little farther to make sure the intersection was clear before she proceeded.Â  
  The jury could have reasonably inferred from her testimony that Keels indeed 
  stopped and, after determining Postonâ€™s oncoming vehicle did not constitute 
  an immediate hazard, proceeded lawfully through the intersection.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2330 (2003) (requiring that a â€œdriver shall yield the 
  right-of-way to any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another roadway 
  so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time when such driver 
  is moving across or with the intersectionâ€).Â  Because a verdict for Keels would 
  be reasonably possible under the facts presented at trial as liberally construed 
  in her favor, Postonâ€™s motions for directed verdict and JNOV were properly denied.Â  

Poston also argues the trial court 
  erred by declining to grant his motion for a new trial arguing Keels was negligent 
  as a matter of law.Â  We disagree.
Negligence as a matter of law 
  cannot be established in this case unless the only inference that can be drawn 
  from the evidence is that Keels either â€œdid not look or did so in such a careless 
  fashion as not to see what was in plain view.â€Â  Crosby v. Sawyer, 291 
  S.C. 474, 476, 354 S.E.2d 387, 388 (1987).Â  
Because the jury could have determined 
  from her testimony that Keels carefully looked both ways before crossing the 
  intersection, Poston cannot establish she was negligent as a matter of law.Â  
  Accordingly, Postonâ€™s motion for a new trial was properly denied.
Finally, Poston claims the trial 
  court erred by denying his motion for a new trial, arguing the amount of the 
  verdict was so excessive as to indicate that it was the result of passion, prejudice, 
  caprice or conjecture.Â  We disagree.Â  
When we review a juryâ€™s award 
  of damages, this court has a duty only to determine whether any evidence exists 
  to support the verdict.Â  Hutson v. Cummins Carolinas, Inc., 280 S.C. 
  552, 559, 314 S.E.2d 19, 24 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  
Keels testified she suffered painful 
  injuries to her neck and shoulder that resulted in her inability to function 
  as she had prior to the accident.Â  She also testified about medical expenses 
  she had incurred as a result of the accident.Â  Her testimony meets the â€œany 
  evidenceâ€ standard to support the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  We therefore are without 
  grounds to grant a new trial.
II.Â  Admission of Summary of Medical Bills
Poston contends the trial court erred in 
  admitting a summary of Keelsâ€™ medical bills into evidence without requiring 
  her to produce the actual billing statements or evidence the medical charges 
  she incurred were related to injuries claimed as a result of the accident.Â  
  We disagree.
The decision whether to admit 
  or exclude evidence is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial court 
  and it will not be disturbed on appeal absent a showing the court abused that 
  discretion.Â  Gamble v. Intâ€™l Paper Realty Corp. of South Carolina, 323 
  S.C. 367, 373, 474 S.E.2d 438, 441 (1996).Â  Moreover, whether a plaintiffâ€™s 
  medical bills are sufficiently related to the injuries sustained in the accident 
  from which the litigation arose is a question of fact for the jury to determine, 
  and only goes to the weight, not the admissibility of the evidence.Â  Pilgrim 
  v. Miller, 350 S.C. 637, 643, 567 S.E.2d 527, 530 (Ct. App. 2002).
Although Keels did not submit 
  her actual medical bills into evidence, she provided a summary of her medical 
  expenses and testified to its accuracy and to the relationship of the expenses 
  contained within it to the injuries she sustained as a result of the auto accident.Â  
  We therefore conclude the trial court did not abuse his discretion in admitting 
  a summary of Keelsâ€™ medical expenses into evidence.
III.Â  Hearsay 
  Testimony
Poston claims the trial court 
  erred in allowing Keelsâ€™ counsel to ask her a leading question during redirect 
  containing a hearsay assertion.Â  We disagree.Â  
On cross-examination Postonâ€™s 
  counsel asked Keels, â€œTo your knowledge did Dr. Trefny, your family doctor, 
  attribute these injuries, your neck and your left shoulder, to this accident?â€Â  
  Keels responded, â€œ[w]ell he treated me for it.â€Â  On redirect examination, Keelsâ€™ 
  attorney asked her, â€œDid Dr. Trefny indicate whether or not he thought that 
  the injury to your neck and shoulder came from the accident?â€Â  Keels attempted 
  to respond:Â  â€œHe told me had to come from that because . . .â€Â  Postonâ€™s counsel 
  interrupted Keelsâ€™ reply, objecting solely on the grounds her answer constituted 
  inadmissible hearsay.Â  The trial court overruled the objection, determining 
  Keelsâ€™ answer was â€œresponsive to questions posed during cross-examination.â€Â  
  We agree.Â  
On appeal, Keels claims error not only 
  on the grounds of hearsay, but also that the question was leading.Â  No objection 
  was interposed on the basis the question was leading.Â  Therefore, that issue 
  is not preserved for our review.Â  State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 
  S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989) (Appellant may not object to evidence on one ground at 
  trial and then argue an alternate ground on appeal.).Â  
The question posed on redirect 
  and Keelsâ€™ response was invited by opposing counselâ€™s questioning during cross-examination.Â  
  Because Postonâ€™s counsel initiated inquiry into this subject, Poston is now 
  in no position to complain about a continuation of the same line of questioning.Â  
  Kirkland v. Peoples Gas Co., 269 S.C. 431, 437, 237 S.E.2d 772, 774-75 
  (1977) (holding a party may not complain on appeal of an error invited by the 
  partyâ€™s own conduct); Squires v. Henderson, 208 S.C. 58, 63-64, 36 S.E.2d 
  738, 740-41 (1946) (stating when an appellant initiates a line of questioning, 
  the appellant cannot later complain as to that same line of questioning).
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to 
    Rule 215, SCACR.Â

PER CURIAM:Â  Delbert R. Tangeman appeals from a jury verdict in favor

Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, 
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney 
  General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Randolph Murdaugh, 
  III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The issue on appeal is whether a magistrate exceeded her 
  authority by imposing fines, administrative fees, and court costs when she sentenced 
  a defendant to consecutive jail terms exceeding 90 days on fraudulent check 
  charges.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On October 21, 2002, Herber E. Mixson was sentenced in magistrateâ€™s 
  court to 44 consecutive 30-day sentences on fraudulent check charges.Â  After 
  serving the first three sentences, Mixson had the option of avoiding further 
  incarceration by paying the amount of the checks plus fines, assessments, administrative 
  costs, and service charges totaling $166 per warrant and conviction. 
Mixson appealed to the circuit court, contending that, under South 
  Carolina Code section 22-3-550(B), the magistrate was required to set an amount 
  of restitution in lieu of any sentence over 90 days and this amount could not 
  include court costs, assessments, and fines. [2] Â  The circuit court affirmed the 
  magistrateâ€™s sentences.
Pursuant to Anders v. California, 
  [3]  Mixsonâ€™s appellate counsel filed an appeal and a petition to be relieved 
  as counsel.Â  This court denied counselâ€™s petition to be relieved and ordered 
  the parties to brief the issues of whether the magistrate violated section 22-3-550(B) 
  by (1) ordering Mixson to serve consecutive jail terms exceeding 90 days or 
  pay fines in addition to restitution, and (2) ordering Mixson to serve consecutive 
  jail terms exceeding 90 days or, in the alternative, to pay administrative fees 
  and costs in addition to restitution.
LAW/ANALYSIS
During oral argument before the circuit court and in his appeal to 
  this court, Mixson argued that the language in section 22-3-550(B) requiring 
  a magistrate to â€œspecify an amount of restitution in damages at the time of 
  sentencing as an alternative to any imprisonment of more than ninety days which 
  is lawfully imposedâ€ precludes a magistrate from fining, assessing, or charging 
  a defendant after the first three offenses. [4] Â  We disagree.Â  
Nothing in section 22-3-550(B) limits a magistrateâ€™s authority to levy fines, 
  assessments, and court costs on defendants who receive three or more consecutive 
  sentences for fraudulent check violations.Â  This section does not specify that 
  restitution is to be the sole consequence of an alternative to imprisonment 
  of more than 90 days; rather, it merely requires magistrates to grant persistent 
  fraudulent check offenders the opportunity to shorten the time they must spend 
  in confinement.
We further agree with the circuit court that section 22-3-550 must 
  be read in pari materia with other statutes that address the jurisdiction 
  of the magistrateâ€™s court over fraudulent check charges. [5] Â  In particular, South Carolina Code section 
  34-11-90 provides that a fraudulent check charge â€œmust be tried exclusively 
  in magistrates courtâ€ if the amount of the instrument is $1,000 or less. 
  [6] Â  
Paragraph (a) of section 34-11-90 sets minimum and maximum fines for a magistrate 
  to impose for fraudulent check convictions if the offender is not sentenced 
  to imprisonment. [7] Â  Under paragraph (d) of this 
  section, a defendant convicted of drawing and uttering a fraudulent check or 
  other instrument â€œshall pay in addition to the fine all reasonable court 
  costs accruing, not to exceed forty-one dollars.â€ [8] Â  
Similarly, section 14-1-207(A) mandates that â€œa person who is convicted of, 
  pleads guilty or nolo contendere to, or forfeits bond for an offense tried in 
  magistrateâ€™s court must pay an amount equal to 100 percent of the fine 
  imposed as an assessment.â€ [9] 
Considering all these statutes together, as we must, we hold the requirement 
  in section 22-3-550 for a magistrate to specify an amount of restitution as 
  an alternative to any imprisonment of more than 90 days does not restrict the 
  authority of the magistrate to order payment of fines, assessments, and court 
  costs in these cases.Â  Indeed, to hold otherwise would undermine the legislative 
  mandate that these surcharges be imposed.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court 
    in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument 
    pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2] Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-550(B) (Supp. 
    2004) (concerning time limitations for consecutive sentences imposed by magistrates).

 
   [3] Â  386 U.S. 738 (1967).

 
   
    [4] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-550(B) (Supp. 2004).Â  Mixson conceded the 
    magistrate could require him to pay the amounts of the fraudulent checks and 
    up to a $25 service charge per check as restitution.Â  See id. 
    Â§ 34-11-70(a)(3) (Supp. 2004) (providing for a service charge â€œsolely to compensate 
    the payee of [a fraudulent] instrument for incurred expenses in processing 
    the dishonored instrumentâ€).Â  The legislature amended this section in 2002 
    to increase the maximum amount of the charge to $30.

 
   
    [5] Â  See Grant v. City of Folly Beach, 346 S.C. 74, 79, 
    551 S.E.2d 229, 231 (2001) (stating that statutes dealing with the same subject 
    should be construed together to produce a harmonious result).

 
   [6] Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-11-90 (Supp. 2004) (emphasis 
    added).

 
   [7] Â  Id. Â§ 34-11-90(a)(1) through (4).Â  The 
    ranges of the fines vary according to the amount of the instrument and whether 
    the conviction is a first conviction or a second or subsequent conviction.

 
   [8] Â  Id. Â§ 34-11-90(d) (emphasis added).

 
   [9] Â  Id. Â§ 14-1-207(A) (emphasis added).

title: Campbell v. Caligiuri
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lyman Campbell, Appellant,
v.
Laura Caligiuri, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-044
Submitted November 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  19, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Chad L. Bacon, of Greenville, for Appellant.
A. Marvin Quattlebaum, Jr. and Peter G. Siachos, both of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Lyman Campbell brought this action against Laura Caligiuri 
  for payment of a real estate sales commission.Â  After a jury returned a verdict 
  in favor of Caliguiri, the trial court awarded her attorneyâ€™s fees, pursuant 
  to the partiesâ€™ exclusive buyer agency agreement.Â  Campbell appeals.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In the spring of 2002, Caligiuri contacted Campbell, a realtor, about 
  purchasing a home in the Greenville area.Â  Caligiuri was new to the area, having 
  accepted a position with Greenville Hospital Systems, which referred her to 
  Campbell.Â  On April 12, 2002, Caliguiri and Campbell entered into an â€œexclusive 
  buyer agency agreement.â€Â  Two days after entering into the agreement, Caligiuri, 
  through Campbell, made an offer on a house.Â  The offer was accepted.Â  Caligiuri 
  and the seller entered into a contract for sale on April 14, 2002.Â  
Caligiuri applied for financing from Palmetto Bank.Â  Palmetto Bank 
  granted Caliguiri loan approval, contingent upon the liquidation of certain 
  assets, including her IRA account, for the down payment and closing costs.Â Â  
  Prior to closing, Caligiuri contacted the loan officer and stated she had decided 
  not to liquidate any assets but wanted to pursue an interim loan for the down 
  payment and closing costs.Â  The loan officer informed her that the additional 
  loan payment would make her loan unapprovable.Â  Caligiuri then withdrew her 
  application for financing.Â  The contract for sale of the house expired May 31, 
  2002.Â  Caligiuri did not purchase another house in the Greenville area.Â  
Although the closing never occurred on the property, Campbell brought 
  this action against Caligiuri for breach of contract and bad faith seeking payment 
  of a real estate commission, actual and punitive damages, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
  The case was tried before a jury.Â  The jury returned verdict in favor of Caligiuri.Â  
  The trial court subsequently awarded her $7600.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This 
  appeal followed.Â  
Standard of Review
In reviewing the denial of motions for directed verdict and JNOV, the evidence 
  and the reasonable inferences that can be drawn therefrom must be viewed in 
  the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Brady Dev. Co. v. Town 
  of Hilton Head Island, 312 S.C. 73, 78, 439 S.E.2d 266, 269 (1993); Evans 
  v. Taylor Made Sandwich Co., 337 S.C. 95, 99, 522 S.E.2d 350, 352 (Ct. App. 
  1999).Â  The motion should be denied where the â€œevidence yields more than one 
  inference or its inference is in doubt.â€Â  Evans, 337 S.C. at 99, 522 
  S.E.2d at 352.Â  When considering the motion, neither the appellate court nor 
  the circuit court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts 
  in the testimony and evidence.Â  Reiland v. Southland Equip. Serv., Inc., 
  330 S.C. 617, 634, 500 S.E.2d 145, 154 (Ct. App. 1998).
Discussion
Campbell argues the trial court erred in not holding that he was 
  entitled to his commission as a matter of law.Â  We disagree.
â€œAs a general rule, a broker has earned his commission when he procures a purchaser 
  who is accepted by the owner of the property and with whom the latter enters 
  into a valid and enforceable contract.â€Â  Champion v. Whaley, 280 S.C. 
  116, 119, 311 S.E.2d 404, 406 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  However, the broker and principal 
  may make the right to the commission contingent upon the occurrence of certain 
  events.Â  Hamrick v. Cooper River Lumber Co., 223 S.C. 119, 124, 74 S.E.2d 
  575, 577 (1953); Chambers v. Pingree, 351 S.C. 442, 451, 570 S.E.2d 528, 
  532 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  A broker suing to recover his commission has the burden 
  of proving all the conditions precedent to his right to performance have occurred.Â  
  Chambers, 351 S.C. at 451, 570 S.E.2d 528 at 532.
We look to the exclusive agency agreement to determine when Campbellâ€™s commission 
  is deemed to be earned.Â  In construing a contract, the primary purpose of the 
  court is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the parties.Â  Schulmeyer 
  v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 
  134 (2003).Â  â€œWhen a contract is unambiguous a court must construe its provisions 
  according to the terms the parties used; understood in their plain, ordinary, 
  and popular sense.â€Â  Id.Â  A contract is ambiguous when it is capable 
  of more than one meaning or when its meaning is unclear.Â  Ellie, Inc. v. 
  Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 93, 594 S.E.2d 485, 493 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In ascertaining 
  intent with an ambiguous contract, the court will strive to discover the situation 
  of the parties, along with their purposes at the time the contract was entered.Â  
  Id.Â  Any ambiguity in the construction of the agreement must be resolved 
  against Campbell, who prepared the agreement.Â  See Hamrick, 223 
  S.C. at 126, 74 S.E.2d at 578.
Here, the exclusive agency agreement provides:

Buyer understands that commission payable to Broker under Section 4 below shall 
  be deemed earned upon Buyer and Seller entering into a binding contract for 
  real estate to which this Agreement applies, whether or not Broker was directly 
  involved in the transaction leading to such contract.Â  

The agreement further provides:

The Broker is directed to first seek compensation from the transaction at closing. 
  . . .Â  If Buyer elects to acquire such property, Buyer shall pay Broker an amount 
  equal to the difference in any fee received by the Buyerâ€™s Broker from the listing 
  broker and a total fee of not less than three percent (3%) of the gross price 
  of the transaction, or amount equal to the CM code offered by the listing broker, 
  whichever is greatest.Â  

We find that even if Campbellâ€™s commission was not contingent upon 
  closing, it was still not earned until Caligiuri had entered into a binding, 
  and thus valid and enforceable, contract for sale.Â  There is no question that 
  Caligiuri entered into a valid contract with a seller.Â  See Champion, 
  280 S.C. at 122, 311 S.E.2d at 408 (â€œThe fact that no duty of performance can 
  arise until the happening of a condition does not make the existence of the 
  contract depend upon its happening, unless the parties so intend.â€).Â  Although 
  the contract states that it is a binding contract, it also provides:Â  â€œThe obligation 
  of Purchaser to purchase is contingent upon the Purchaser obtaining a loan in 
  the amount of 90% of the purchase price.â€Â  Thus, the contract only became enforceable 
  and thus binding against Caligiuri upon her meeting this contingency.Â  The real 
  estate agreement, which provides Campbell earned his commission upon Calguiri 
  entering into a binding contract, encompasses the same contingency.Â  
It is undisputed Caliguiri never received a loan commitment.Â  
  However, as a general rule, one who prevents a condition of a contract cannot 
  rely on the other partyâ€™s resulting nonperformance in an action on the contract.Â  
  Champion, 280 S.C. at 120, 311 S.E.2d at 406. 

It is sufficient for the plaintiff to present evidence that 
  the defendantâ€™s prevention â€œsubstantially contributedâ€ to the nonoccurrence 
  of the condition.Â  Once he has made such proof, the burden shifts to the defendant.Â  
  If the defendant can show that the condition would not have occurred regardless 
  of the prevention, then the prevention did not contribute materially to its 
  nonoccurrence and the condition is not excused.

Id., at 122, 311 S.E.2d at 407 (citation omitted).Â  The prevention of 
  the condition precedent must be intentional or entail wrongdoing.Â  Chambers, 
  351 S.C. at 451, 570 S.E.2d 528 at 532.
When Caligiuri applied for financing, she had not sold her house in Florida 
  at the time and had initially planned on liquidating her IRA account to fund 
  her down payment and closing costs.Â  Palmetto Bank pre-qualified Caligiuri for 
  a loan, granting her approval contingent upon her liquidating these assets.Â  
  In liquidating her IRA account, Caligiuri would have incurred penalties and 
  fees.Â  Rather than incur these penalties and fees, Caligiuri attempted to acquire 
  an additional loan to fund the closing.Â  It was not until the bank rejected 
  this attempt that Caligiuri withdrew her loan application.Â  The seller is not 
  required to put the brokerâ€™s interests ahead of his own.Â Â  Chambers, 
  351 S.C. at 453, 570 S.E.2d 528 at 534.
We find the evidence supports the conclusion that Caligiuri was not acting 
  in bad faith or intentionally trying to deprive Campbell of his fee but was 
  merely protecting her own financial interest.Â  
Furthermore, Palmetto Bankâ€™s loan officer testified that even if Caligiuri 
  had liquidated her assets, she would not have been approved for the loan because 
  her debt ratio was too high.Â  Thus, regardless of Caligiuriâ€™s withdrawal of 
  the application, she would not have been able to obtain financing and meet the 
  condition precedent.Â  
As the condition precedent of obtaining financing was not excused or met, the 
  contract of sale never became enforceable against Caligiuri.Â  Absent an enforceable, 
  and thus binding contract, Campbell was not entitled to a commission.Â  We find 
  the trial court did not err in denying Campbellâ€™s motions for directed verdict 
  and JNOV.Â  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.Â

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Charleston County Department of Social Services,
Respondent,
v.
Willie Mae Grant, William Creel and John DoeÂ  andÂ Â  Ke Shundra Charmain 
        Bianca Creel, a child, D/O/B 5/29/91; W. Jay Zahn Asaas Armand Creel, 
        II, a child, D/O/B 12/16/92, Defendants,
of whom William Creel is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â FrancesÂ  P. Segars-Andrews, Family 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-046
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  19, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
B. Craig Killough and 
  Arthur C. Pelzer, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
Frampton Durban, Jr. 
  and Sally C. Dey, both of North Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this family court action, William 
  Creel alleges the trial court erred in terminating his parental rights.Â  Creel 
  fails to take exception, however, to a number of grounds on which the family 
  court relied.Â  Failure to argue these issues is an abandonment and precludes 
  consideration of them on appeal.Â  Biales v. Young, 315 S.C. 166, 168, 
  432 S.E.2d 482, 484 (1993).Â  Furthermore, where a trial court rules on more 
  than one ground, an unappealed ground will become the law of the case and the 
  trial courtâ€™s ruling will be affirmed.Â  Anderson v. Short, 323 S.C. 522, 
  525, 476 S.E.2d 475, 477 (1996).Â  
The family court based termination of Creelâ€™s parental 
  rights, in part, on the fact that the children have been in foster care for 
  15 of the last 22 months and have been out of the home for six months and the 
  parent has not remedied the conditions which caused their removal.Â  See 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(2) & (8) (Supp. 2004).Â  After a thorough review 
  of the record we are convinced that termination is in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  
  See Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 
  (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family courtâ€™s decision.Â  See 
  Dwyer v. Tom Jenkins Realty, Inc., 289 S.C. 118, 120-121, 344 S.E.2d 
  886, 888 (Ct. App. 1986) (affirming the circuit court when unchallenged alternative 
  findings support the judgment); 5 Am. Jur. 2d Appellate Review Â§ 829 
  at 489 (1995) (â€œwhere a separate and independent ground from the one appealed 
  supports the judgment made below, and is not challenged on appeal, the appellate 
  court must affirm.â€).Â  In light of our ruling, we need not address the merits 
  of the other issues raised on appeal.Â  See Rule 220 (c), SCACR; Futch 
  v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 
  591, 598 (1999) (holding appellate courts need not address remaining issues 
  when the disposition of a prior issue is dispositive).Â  
AFFIRMED.  [1] 
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Ahlfeldt v. Brown
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO 
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY 
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Harry J. Ahlfeldt and Carol A. Ahlfeldt, Plaintiffs,
v.
Franklin Dean Brown and Catherine Brown, Defendants,
and
Franklin Dean Brown, Third Party Plaintiff, Appellant,
v.
Sea Mark Tower Property Owners Association, Inc., Third Party Defendant,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â JohnÂ  L.Â  Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-047
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  19, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John P. Bacot, Jr., of Surfside Beach, for Appellant.
Michael James Barnett, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Franklin Dean Brown appeals from the trial courtâ€™s order 
  granting summary judgment in favor of Sea Mark Tower Property Owners Association 
  on Brownâ€™s third-party claim for indemnification of legal expenses.Â  We affirm.1Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
Brown and his wife Catherine sold Unit 201 in Sea Mark Towers to 
  Harry and Carol Ahlfeldt on December 1, 1999.Â  The Association thereafter imposed 
  substantial assessments on all of the units for repairs to the common areas.Â  
  The Ahlfeldts sued the Browns for fraud, negligent misrepresentation, and other 
  causes of action alleging the Browns failed to disclose the severe structural 
  defects in the building and the need for the assessments.Â  The Ahlfeldts claimed 
  that as Brown had served on the Associationâ€™s Board of Directors from mid-1995 
  to November of 1997, he knew that the repairs were needed and huge assessments 
  would become necessary.Â  
Brown brought this third party claim against the Association seeking 
  indemnification from the Association for all expenses and liabilities imposed 
  upon him as a result of the Ahlfeldtsâ€™ action, including attorneyâ€™s fees, expenses 
  and any judgment rendered against him.Â  The Association denied Brownâ€™s claim 
  for indemnification and brought a motion for summary judgment.Â  The trial court 
  granted the motion.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
Standard of Review
Summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue as to any material 
  fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Osborne 
  v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  The evidence and all 
  reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to 
  the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  â€œIt is well established that summary judgment 
  should be granted â€˜. . . in cases in which plain, palpable and indisputable 
  facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ.â€™â€Â  Anders v. S.C. Farm 
  Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 307 S.C. 371, 373, 415 S.E.2d 406, 407 (Ct. App. 1992) 
  (quoting Main v. Corley, 281 S.C. 525, 526, 316 S.E.2d 406, 407 (1984)); 
  see Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 425, 529 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2000) 
  (stating where a verdict is not reasonably possible under the facts presented, 
  summary judgment is proper).
Discussion
Brown argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to 
  the Association.Â  We disagree.Â  
Brown claims he is entitled to indemnification under the terms of 
  the Associationâ€™s Articles of Incorporation.Â  The pertinent section provides:

Every Director and every 
  officer of the Corporation shall be indemnified by the Corporation against all 
  expenses and liabilities, including counsel fees, reasonably incurred by or 
  imposed upon him in connection with any proceeding to which he may be a party, 
  or in which he may become involved, by reason of his being or having been a 
  Director or Officer of the Corporation, whether or not he is a Director or Officer 
  at the time such expenses are incurred, except in such cases wherein the Director 
  or Officer is adjudged guilty of willful misfeasance or malfeasance in the performance 
  of his duties; provided, that in the event of any claim for reimbursement of 
  indemnification, the indemnification herein shall only apply if the Board of 
  Directors approves such settlement and reimbursement as being in the best interest 
  of the Corporation.Â  

The trial court held Brown was not entitled to indemnification under this provision 
  because Brown was a party to this action â€œâ€˜by reason ofâ€™ his allegedly having 
  personally defrauded or otherwise breached some duty he may have owed individually 
  to the [Alfeldts] as a seller of his own condominiumâ€ and not â€œâ€˜by reason ofâ€™ 
  his having been a director of the Association two years prior to the sale of 
  his unit.â€Â  The court explained, â€œIn short, the reason Mr. Brown is being 
  sued is that he allegedly failed to fulfill his personal, legal obligation as 
  a seller to disclose any knowledge of latent defects to the buyers, regardless 
  of how or when he may have obtained such knowledge; the reason he is 
  being sued is not because he once served as an Association director.â€ 
As an alternative reason for granting the Association summary judgment, the 
  trial court held Brown was not entitled to indemnification because there was 
  no evidence that the Associationâ€™s Board had approved any settlement or reimbursement 
  for Brown, or that it wrongfully refused to do so.Â  The court found that it 
  would not be in the Associationâ€™s best interest for the Board to indemnify any 
  director in this type of action.Â  The court elucidated:

Absent some special circumstances 
  not present in this case, to allow any condominium homeowners association to 
  indemnify a director for personal liability he incurs as a result of his alleged 
  fraud or other failure to fulfill his personal duties as a seller of his own 
  condominium unit would be improper, could result in claims by members of such 
  association for breach of fiduciary duty against the directors voting to approve 
  such indemnification, and if allowed to stand, could encourage directors to 
  sell their own condominium units upon first learning as directors of construction 
  defects, without disclosing the same to buyers, in anticipation that they would 
  be indemnified by the association (at the expense of all the homeowners) for 
  liability to the buyers resulting from such fraudulent activities.Â  

In his brief, 
  Brown focuses his argument on the trial courtâ€™s first holding that Brown is 
  not entitled to indemnification because he is not a party to the action â€œby 
  reason ofâ€ his having been a director.Â  He largely ignores the courtâ€™s alternate 
  holding that he is not entitled to indemnification because the Board had not 
  approved any request for indemnification and such indemnification was not in 
  the best interest of the corporation.Â  Brown merely recognizes that the court 
  noted this provision in the Articles of Incorporation and states, â€œBrown has 
  made a claim unto the corporation by way of his third-party claim, but no evidence 
  has been submitted that such a claim has been acted upon by the Board.â€Â  
Brown offers no argument as to how he is entitled to indemnification absent 
  the Boardâ€™s approval.Â  He also does not challenge the trial courtâ€™s ruling that 
  allowing such indemnification would not be in the Associationâ€™s best interest.Â  
  An appellant has the burden of convincing this court that the trial judge committed 
  error in his findings.Â  In re Thames, 344 S.C. 564, 571, 544 S.E.2d 854, 
  857 (Ct.App.2001).Â  As Brown failed to meet this burden, we affirm the trial 
  courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of the Association.Â  
 AFFIRMED.Â Â 
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
  1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Meetze v. Saylors
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James A. Meetze, Appellant,
v.
Freda Saylors and Toby O. Saylors, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-049
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  19, 2005

REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Christopher B. Staubes, III, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Freda Saylors and Toby Saylors, pro se Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  James A. Meetze appeals from a circuit court order that 
  granted him summary judgment in his action to enforce restrictive covenants 
  in a residential neighborhood, but denied his request for attorneyâ€™s fees and 
  costs.Â  Meetze argues the circuit court erred in denying his request for attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs because the restrictive covenants provide for an award of both 
  to a prevailing party.Â  We reverse in part and remand. 
  [1] 
FACTS
Meetze filed this action in 2002 against Freda Saylors and Toby Saylors 
  to enforce restrictive covenants in the Pirates Cove subdivision of Mount Pleasant, 
  South Carolina.Â  Meetze alleged in his complaint that the Saylors were in violation 
  of paragraph fourteen of the covenants, which prohibits parking house trailers, 
  mobile homes, campers, or other habitable vehicles, as well as commercial vehicles, 
  on lots within the subdivision.Â  
Meetze included in his complaint a request for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs as 
  provided for by paragraph twenty-two of the covenants, entitled â€œEnforcement 
  of Restrictions.â€Â  This paragraph states in relevant part:Â  

Any owner found by a court of law or equity to be in violation of these covenants 
  and restrictions shall pay a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee to the Plaintiff, together 
  with all costs of litigation.Â  

In 2003, Meetze moved for summary judgment.Â  The circuit court granted 
  Meetzeâ€™s motion and ordered the Saylors to remove any prohibited vehicles parked 
  or stored on their lots.Â  The court noted that Meetze had â€œpresented an affidavit 
  of reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs in the amount of $1,977.50 for fees[] 
  and $161.30 in actual costsâ€ for which he requested recovery pursuant to paragraph 
  twenty-two of the restrictive covenants.Â  The court denied the request, however, 
  and this appeal followed.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Meetze contends the circuit court abused its discretion 
  in denying his request for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs. [2] Â  We agree.
Under South Carolina common law, a prevailing party generally has 
  no right to recover attorneyâ€™s fees unless they are provided for by contract 
  or authorized by statute.Â  Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 486 S.E.2d 
  750 (1997); Harris-Jenkins v. Nissan Car Mart, Inc., 348 S.C. 171, 557 
  S.E.2d 708 (Ct. App. 2001).
In this case, there is a contractual basis for an award of attorneyâ€™s 
  fees.Â  As noted above, paragraph twenty-two of the restrictive covenants expressly 
  provides that any owner found in violation of the covenants by a court â€œshall 
  pay a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee to the Plaintiff, together with all costs 
  of litigation.â€Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  
In Prevatte v. Asbury Arms, 302 S.C. 413, 396 S.E.2d 642 (Ct. App. 1990), 
  this Court considered a provision of the Landlord-Tenant Act that stated a tenant 
  â€œmayâ€ recover â€œreasonable attorneyâ€™s feesâ€ and determined that, to the extent 
  the word â€œmayâ€ connoted discretion, it referred to the tenantâ€™s right to elect 
  a statutory remedy and it did not mean the trial judge could deny a remedy clearly 
  provided for by the statute.Â  Id. at 415, 396 S.E.2d at 643.Â  We concluded 
  â€œ[t]he appellate courts of this state have never construed this language as 
  giving the trial judge discretion to award or deny attorneyâ€™s fees.â€Â  Id. 
  at 416, 396 S.E.2d at 644.Â  Rather, although a fee is recoverable as a matter 
  of right, the amount must be â€œreasonable,â€ and â€œ[w]hat constitutes a reasonable 
  fee is a matter for the court to determine as a matter of informed judicial 
  discretion.â€Â  Id.Â  We observed that, in exercising his or her discretion 
  in deciding the amount of a reasonable fee, the trial judge should be guided 
  by the following factors:Â  

  
    
    
      
        (1)  
         the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered;
      
      
        (2) 
         the time and labor necessarily devoted to the
          case;
      
      
        (3)
         the professional standing of counsel;
      
      
        (4)
         the contingency of compensation;
      
      
        (5) 
         the fee customarily charged in the locality for similar services; and
      
      
        (6) 
         the beneficial results accomplished.Â 
      
    
    
  

Id. at 416-17, 396 S.E.2d at 644.
Although Prevatte dealt with a statutory, rather than a contractual, 
  provision for attorneyâ€™s fees, we find it is sufficiently analogous so that 
  its reasoning is applicable in the current appeal.Â  Here, the restrictive covenants 
  expressly provide that reasonable attorneyâ€™s fees and costs â€œshallâ€ be recoverable 
  by a prevailing party in the event a court finds a homeowner in violation of 
  the covenants.Â  
During the hearing in this matter, when Meetzeâ€™s attorney presented his affidavit 
  for attorneyâ€™s fees, the court stated:Â  â€œEven if I rule in your favor, I -- 
  you can send it up here but Iâ€™m not going to do it, I am not even going to 
  consider your attorneyâ€™s fees even if I rule with you.Â  I think both sides 
  have got a legitimate gripe, problem.â€Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  The court thereafter 
  encouraged the parties to attempt to negotiate a resolution.Â  When that effort 
  failed, the court granted summary judgment to Meetze.Â  The circuit court summarily 
  denied the request for fees and costs in its final order.Â  
We hold the circuit court erred in denying attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to Meetze 
  after finding the Saylors were in violation of the covenants and granting summary 
  judgment to Meetze on this basis.Â  Since the covenants contractually provide 
  a prevailing party with the right to recover attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, the 
  court should have determined what constitutes a reasonable fee in light of the 
  six guidelines listed above.Â  Accordingly, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s order 
  to the extent it denied Meetzeâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs and remand 
  the matter to the circuit court for determination of an appropriate award using 
  the factors outlined above.
REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

 
   
    [2] Â  The Saylors have not filed a Respondentsâ€™ Brief.Â  The South Carolina 
    Appellate Court Rules provide that â€œ[u]pon the failure of respondent to timely 
    file a brief, the appellate court may take such action as it deems proper.â€Â  
    Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR.Â  Such action may include reversal.Â  Turner v. Santee 
    Cement Carriers, Inc., 277 S.C. 91, 282 S.E.2d 858 (1981).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

PER CURIAM: This is an appeal of the trial courtâ€™s refusal to award 


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE
