THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Company,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Henry Berlin and Terry Berlin,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-062
Submitted December 1, 2004 â€“ Filed January 25, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
Andrew Steven Halio, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Claron A. Robertson, III, and Paul E. Sperry, both of Charleston, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this declaratory judgment 
  action concerning insurance coverage, we are asked to determine the efficacy 
  of an exclusion from coverage for â€œloss . . . caused by . . . insectsâ€ in a 
  homeownerâ€™s insurance policy.Â  The insuredâ€™s home was damaged as a result of 
  honey seeping into the ceilings and walls of their home from a honeybee hive.Â  
  While we recognize the rule of construction requiring clauses of exclusion in 
  an insurance policy to be narrowly interpreted, and clauses of inclusion to 
  be broadly construed, we findâ€”based on the stipulated factsâ€”that the loss sustained 
  by the homeowners was â€œcaused byâ€ insects.Â  We conclude, therefore, that the 
  loss is not covered by the policy.Â  In so holding, we reverse the judgment of 
  the circuit court. [1] 
STIPULATED FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
The parties entered into a â€œstipulation 
  of facts.â€Â  A colony of honeybees nested in the walls and ceiling of Henry and 
  Terry Berlinâ€™s home.Â  A hole was cut into the ceiling to ensure that the honeybees 
  were exterminated or abandoned the nests.Â  After the bees abandoned the nest 
  or were exterminated, the honey contained in the hive began to seep down through 
  the walls and ceiling, damaging the home. 
The Berlins notified their homeownerâ€™s 
  insurance carrier, South Carolina Farm Bureau, of the damage.Â  Farm Bureau denied 
  coverage, specifically pointing to a policy provision that excluded coverage 
  for â€œloss . . . caused by . . . birds, vermin, rodents, insects or domestic 
  animals.â€Â  
Farm Bureau subsequently brought this 
  declaratory judgment action seeking a determination that the damage to the Berlinsâ€™ 
  residence was caused by insects and therefore was not a covered loss under the 
  policy exclusion.Â  The Berlins counterclaimed for breach of contract.Â  Upon 
  consideration of the partiesâ€™ cross motions for summary judgment, the circuit 
  court found the language in the policy exclusionâ€”specifically the phrase â€œcaused 
  byâ€â€”was ambiguous and construed it against Farm Bureau.Â  The circuit court thus 
  found the damage from the dripping honey was not caused by insects under the 
  policy language and granted judgment in favor of the Berlins. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
As noted above, the motion for summary judgment 
  at issue in this appeal was decided by the circuit court on facts stipulated 
  by the parties.Â  After a thorough review of the record, we find no argument 
  raised to the circuit court that a question of material fact existed.Â  To the 
  contrary, both parties suggested that the dispute was essentially legal in nature, 
  and therefore ripe for final disposition at the summary judgment stage.Â  In 
  cases with stipulated facts, this courtâ€™s review is limited to â€œwhether the 
  trial court properly applied the law to those facts.â€ Kay v. State Farm Mut. 
  Auto. Ins. Co., 349 S.C. 446, 448, 562 S.E.2d 676, 678 (Ct. App. 2002) (quoting 
  WDW Props. v. City of Sumter, 342 S.C. 6, 10, 535 S.E.2d 631, 632 (2000)).Â  
  Were we to now entertain arguments on appeal that a question of fact precluded 
  summary judgment, this court would violate the longstanding rule that we only 
  address those issues properly raised and argued below.Â  See, e.g., 
  Schofield v. Richland County School Dist., 316 S.C. 78, 82, 447 S.E.2d 
  189, 191 (1994) (holding that an issue may not be raised for the first time 
  on appeal, but must have been raised to the trial judge to be preserved for 
  appellate review).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Farm Bureau claims the circuit court erred 
  in granting summary judgment in favor of the Berlins.Â  Specifically, Farm Bureau 
  argues the policy language excluding coverage for damage caused by insects was 
  not ambiguous and that the Berlinsâ€™ losses resulting from the honey seepage 
  fell squarely within that coverage exclusion.Â  We agree.
Resolution of this coverage question hinges 
  on the interpretation of the policy language excluding coverage for â€œloss . 
  . . caused by . . .Â  insects.â€ [2] Â  Insurance policies are subject to the general 
  rules of contract construction. Fritz-Pontiac-Cadillac-Buick v. Goforth, 
  312 S.C. 315, 318, 440 S.E.2d 367, 369 (1994). When the language of an insurance 
  contract is free from ambiguity, the words used must be taken and understood 
  in their plain, ordinary and popular sense, and such construction is for the 
  court. Id.Â  An insurerâ€™s obligation under a policy of insurance is defined 
  by the terms of the policy itself, and cannot be enlarged by judicial construction. 
  Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Commercial Bank, 325 S.C. 357, 360, 479 S.E.2d 
  524, 526 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  It is true that ambiguous or conflicting terms in 
  an insurance policy must be construed liberally in favor of the insured and 
  strictly against the insurer. Diamond State Ins. Co. v. Homestead Indus., 
  Inc., 318 S.C. 231, 236, 456 S.E.2d 912, 915 (1995). Moreover, â€œrules of 
  construction require clauses of exclusion to be narrowly interpreted, and clauses 
  of inclusion to be broadly construed.â€ McPherson v. Michigan Mut. Ins. Co., 
  310 S.C. 316, 319, 426 S.E.2d 770, 771 (1993). Â Â Â However, these rules of construction, 
  inuring to the benefit of the insured, do not trump clear and unambiguous policy 
  terms.Â  Where the intention of the parties is clear, courts have no authority 
  to torture the meaning of policy language to extend coverage that was never 
  intended by the parties. Diamond State, 318 S.C. at 236, 456 S.E.2d at 
  915.
We are presented with the narrow question:Â  
  Was the damage to the Berlinsâ€™ home from the honey seeping from the honeybee 
  hive â€œcaused byâ€ the honeybees?Â  In light of the stipulated facts, we answer 
  the question in the affirmative, for there is indisputably a direct and immediate 
  causal relationship between the honeybees and resulting damage from the honeybee 
  hive.Â  
The Berlins argue that the phrase â€œcaused byâ€ in 
  an insurance policy inclusion clause warrants a broad and expansive interpretation 
  and, conversely, a narrower interpretation in the context of a policy exclusion.Â  
  We agree, but that distinction does not, we believe, justify our rejection of 
  the policy exclusion here.Â  See King v. North River Ins. Co., 
  278 S.C. 411, 413, 297 S.E.2d 637, 638 (1982) (construing a clause of inclusion 
  broadly, noting that â€œit is generally sufficient to prove the event insured 
  against was the efficient cause of the loss, even though not the sole 
  causeâ€);Â  Stevenson v. Connecticut General Life Ins. Co., 265 S.C. 348, 
  349-50, 218 S.E.2d 427, 430 (1975) (construing a clause of inclusion broadly, 
  holding that policy language insuring against losses resulting from an accidental 
  bodily injury â€œdirectly and independently of all other causesâ€ should be interpreted 
  as meaning those losses â€œproximately caused by the accidental bodily injury, 
  even though some other cause may have contributed to a minor degreeâ€); Lesley 
  v. American Sec. Ins. Co., 261 S.C. 178, 182-83, 199 S.E.2d 82, 84-85 (1973) 
  (interpreting a policy inclusion clause insuring losses â€œdirectly and immediately 
  resulting from . . . fire and lightningâ€ as meaning losses proximately caused 
  by fire and lightningâ€”specifically opining that â€œthe terms â€˜proximate and immediateâ€™ 
  are virtually synonymousâ€);Â  7 Lee R. Russ & Thomas F. Segalla, Couch 
  on Insurance Â§ 101:40, at 101-127 to 101-129 (3d ed. 1999) (â€œthe rule of 
  causation applied in the context of insurance coverage is â€˜proximate causeâ€™â€)Â Â  
  (footnotes omitted).Â Â  This rule of liberal construction in favor of the insured, 
  to be sure, requires a different interpretation and application of the same 
  causal-relationship phrase when it is part of a clause of exclusion.Â  Where 
  we part ways with the Berlinsâ€™ analysis is their conclusion that this rule of 
  construction, standing alone, mandates a rejection of the policy exclusion before 
  us and a finding of coverage.Â  We adhere to the view that the phrase â€œcaused 
  byâ€ in an exclusion clause retains some meaning and efficacy, albeit a narrow 
  and restricted meaning.
The case of McPherson v. Michigan Mutual Insurance 
  Co. provides some guidance.Â  In McPherson, our supreme court granted 
  certiorari to review a decision of this court.Â  We had held that the City of 
  Charlestonâ€™s general liability insurance policy excluded coverage for McPhersonâ€™s 
  injuries resulting from a collision with a Charleston police vehicle.Â  McPherson 
  v. Michigan Mut. Ins. Co., 306 S.C. 456, 412 S.E.2d 445 (Ct. App. 1991), 
  affâ€™d as modified, 310 S.C. 316, 426 S.E.2d 770 (1993).Â  
  The supreme court affirmed in result, but found fault with this courtâ€™s construction 
  of the relevant policy exclusion.Â  Recognizing that the phrase in the exclusionary 
  clauseâ€”â€œarising out ofâ€â€”is subject to many interpretations, the supreme court 
  noted that this court erred when it â€œrelied primarily on cases construing clauses 
  of inclusion to interpret the phrase â€˜arising out ofâ€™ in the exclusion provision 
  of Charlestonâ€™s general liability policy.â€ McPherson, 310 S.C. at 319, 
  426 S.E.2d at 771.Â  The supreme court adopted a construction of the phrase in 
  the exclusion provision â€œmost favorable to the insured.â€ Id. at 319-20, 
  426 S.E.2d at 771.Â  The court held â€œthat for the purpose of construing an exclusionary 
  clause in a general liability policy, â€˜arising out ofâ€™ should be narrowly construed 
  as â€˜caused by.â€™ However, we find that even under a narrow construction 
  of the exclusion, the injuries . . . are not covered under the policy.â€Â  Id. 
  at 320, 426 S.E.2d at 771-72 (emphasis added).Â  We similarly conclude that even 
  under a narrow construction, the damage to the Berlinsâ€™ home was â€œcaused byâ€ 
  the honeybees.
The stipulated facts lead to the inescapable 
  conclusion that the cause of the damage to the Berlinsâ€™ home was the activity 
  of the honeybees themselves.Â  Were we required to resort to an attenuated proximate 
  cause analysis to link the damage to the Berlinsâ€™ home to the honeybees, the 
  rule in McPherson would compel a different result.Â  Here, however, the 
  nexus between the honeybees, honey, and damage is immediate and direct.Â  It 
  belies common sense and experience to suggest that, merely because the homeowners 
  took measures to eliminate an insect infestation, the causal connection to the 
  insects themselves is broken such that the natural, consequential effects of 
  the insect activity are no longer subject to a standard policy exclusion for 
  damage â€œcaused byâ€ insects.
CONCLUSION
We find the damage to the Berlinsâ€™ home was caused 
  by the honeybees and that Farm Bureau properly relied on the applicable exclusion 
  in denying coverage.Â  The judgment of the circuit court is
REVERSED.
 HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
  Â Â Â Â  
    [1] In fairness to the able circuit judge, our holding is grounded on authority 
    that was not presented to him.

 
  Â Â Â Â  
    [2] The parties stipulated that â€œ[a] honeybee is an â€˜insectâ€™ under the policy.â€

THIS
OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE. 
IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT
AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
John R. Gentry, III,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Doris Gentry,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Jack Alan Landis, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-063
Heard December 14, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  25, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Peggy McMillan Infinger, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Joseph Todd Manley, of Moncks Corner, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this divorce action, the 
  wife, Doris Gentry, appeals the approval of a settlement agreement and the award 
  of attorneyâ€™s fees to the husband, John R. Gentry, III.Â  We affirm in part, 
  reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
The parties married in 1985 and 
  had one child together.Â  They separated in March 1997.Â  On April 28, 2003, the 
  husband commenced this action for a divorce based on a one-year separation, 
  sole custody of the minor child, child support, uncovered medical expenses for 
  the minor child, a bar on alimony, and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  He also filed a notice 
  of motion and motion for temporary relief on various issues incident to the 
  divorce.Â  The wife was served with these documents by certified mail, return 
  receipt requested, on May 16, 2003; however, counsel for the husband admitted 
  at the hearing that he could not produce a signed return receipt.Â  
The temporary hearing was scheduled for June 9, 
  2003, twenty-four days after the wife received the pleadings.Â  On June 6, 2003, 
  three days before the hearing, counsel for the husband sent the wife by facsimile 
  a proposed settlement agreement.Â  The agreement provided the husband would receive 
  most of the marital assets, including the marital home, real property in Aiken, 
  his vehicle, his retirement, and â€œall assets currently in his name and/or possessionâ€ 
  whereas the wife would receive only her vehicle and â€œall assets currently in 
  her name and/or possession,â€ as well as visitation with the partiesâ€™ child.Â  
  It further granted the husband sole care, custody, and control of the partiesâ€™ 
  child and required him to pay the childâ€™s uncovered medical expenses.Â  Neither 
  party would be liable for alimony or responsible for the attorneyâ€™s fees of 
  the other party.Â  The wife, who was not represented by counsel at the time, 
  signed the agreement at the office of the husbandâ€™s attorney, apparently just 
  before the hearing took place.Â  
At the hearing, the wife, still proceeding without 
  counsel, waived her right to object to defects in the service of the summons 
  and complaint.Â  She also waived her right to respond to the pleadings and agreed 
  to proceed with the final hearing.Â  After questioning the wife about her understanding 
  of the agreement and taking testimony from the husband, the family court, ruling 
  from the bench, granted the divorce and approved the settlement agreement.Â  

 Three days after the hearing but before 
  the filing of the final order, the wife retained counsel and filed an answer 
  and counterclaim in which she requested dismissal of the husbandâ€™s complaint, 
  an equitable apportionment of the marital assets, and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  
  These responsive pleadings were filed within thirty days after the wife received 
  the summons and complaint.Â  The wifeâ€™s attorney also requested the family court 
  to â€œreconsider its findings before signing an order approving the agreement.â€ 
  Â The family court, however, after reviewing counselâ€™s request, declined to delay 
  the matter, instructed the husbandâ€™s attorney to prepare an order granting the 
  divorce and approving the agreement, and advised the wifeâ€™s attorney to file 
  appropriate post-trial motions.Â  The final order approving the agreement was 
  filed on July 22, 2003.Â  
The wife, through her attorney, then moved pursuant 
  to Rule 52(b), SCRCP, for reconsideration of the final order, noting (1) she 
  had only an eighth-grade education and poor reading skills; (2) she had been 
  treated over the last six years for depression, anxiety, and stress; and (3) 
  she was not provided with the husbandâ€™s financial declaration until she entered 
  the courtroom at the commencement of the temporary hearing.Â  She further alleged 
  that, because of these circumstances, along with the fact that she did not have 
  an attorney at the hearing, she executed the agreement under duress.Â  In support 
  of her motion, she submitted two affidavits, one from a vocational consultant 
  and the other from a mental health counselor.Â  The vocational consultant attested 
  to her tenth-grade reading and comprehension level.Â  The mental health counselor 
  recounted her history of depression and other impairments and opined that her 
  emotional problems, together with her lack of counsel, caused her to be â€œflooded 
  with anxiety and irrational thinkingâ€ when she appeared before the family court.Â  
  The wife also included her own affidavit, in which she alleged she did not receive 
  the husbandâ€™s financial declaration until â€œthe middle of the hearing in the 
  courtroomâ€ and, until that time, was unaware of both the husbandâ€™s income and 
  the property the parties had accumulated during their marriage.Â  She further 
  alleged that, although she had reservations during the hearing about the husbandâ€™s 
  financial declaration, she felt intimidated by the courtroom setting and was 
  afraid to reveal her concerns to the court.
The family court issued an order denying the motion 
  and granting the husband $1,292.29 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  The order 
  noted these costs were incurred by the husband in defending the motion.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
In the interest of judicial efficiency, 
  the courts of this State have consistently encouraged litigants to reach agreements 
  on issues arising out of the marital relationship. [1] Â  Before approving an agreement, however, the family court must 
  ascertain that both parties have entered into the agreement freely and voluntarily and examine the 
  fairness of the agreement under all the circumstances. 
  [2]   
1.Â  We disagree with the wifeâ€™s assertion of error 
  in the family courtâ€™s determination that she entered into the settlement agreement 
  freely and voluntarily.Â  In denying the wifeâ€™s Rule 52(b) motion, the family 
  court, after reviewing the transcript of record from the hearing, found the 
  wife gave responses indicating that she understood the legal proceedings and 
  terms of the agreement, entered into the agreement freely and without coercion, 
  and fully understood the consequences of the agreement.Â  After reviewing the 
  record, we find no reason to hold otherwise. [3] 
In our view, the affidavits the wife submitted, when 
  considered with what transpired at the family court hearing, do not warrant 
  a finding that she lacked the capacity to agree to the terms of the settlement. 
  [4] Â  In response to the courtâ€™s inquiry as to whether she had entered into 
  the agreement freely and voluntarily, the wife answered unequivocally in the 
  affirmative.Â  She further acknowledged, without any apparent hesitation, that 
  (1) no one had forced her to enter into the agreement against her will; (2) 
  both at the time she signed the agreement and at the time of the hearing, she 
  was not under the influence of drugs, alcohol, medication, stress, illness, 
  or anything else that would have compromised her ability to understand either 
  the agreement or the proceedings that were taking place; and (3) she had enough 
  time to see an attorney had she desired representation and understood that the 
  husbandâ€™s attorney did not represent her.Â  The family court found these responses 
  adequate to support its determination that the wife freely and voluntarily entered 
  into the settlement agreement, and we see no reason not to defer to this finding. [5] Â  In particular, we note that 
  the wife had three days to review the separation agreement outside the presence 
  of both the husband and his attorney before she voluntarily went alone to the 
  office of the husbandâ€™s attorney to sign the agreement.
2.Â  We agree, however, with the wife that the family court 
  should have held a hearing after she timely filed her answer and counterclaim 
  to determine if the agreement was fair and reasonable under the circumstances.
We find instructive the early decision of Drawdy 
  v. Drawdy, [6]  wherein the 
  supreme court discussed the responsibility of the family court when asked to 
  approve a separation agreement:

We think it incumbent on the family court, where 
  one party seeks to enforce and the other to repudiate a property settlement 
  agreement to be incorporated into a subsequent divorce decree, to satisfy itself 
  the agreement is a fair contractual end to the partiesâ€™ marital claims.Â  This 
  cannot be done without examining the agreement in light of the economic circumstances 
  and contributions of each party. 
  [7] Â  

The divorce decree in this case states the agreement 
  is â€œsubstantively fair and reasonable to the parties in light of their testimonyâ€; 
  however, it does not explain why the family court found such a disproportionate 
  division of marital assets to be equitable.Â  The comments made from the bench 
  by the presiding family court judge do little if anything to remedy this lack 
  of information, let alone show that the agreement was examined in light of the 
  economic circumstances and contributions of both the husband and the wife.Â  
  The wife, then, having timely filed an answer and counterclaim, should have 
  been given the opportunity to present testimony on the allegations in her pleadings 
  concerning equitable apportionment and attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, particularly 
  her claims that she made material and non-material contributions to the acquisition 
  of the assets of the marriage.
3.Â  Finally, the wife argues the family court erred 
  in awarding the husband attorneyâ€™s fees for defending her post-trial motion.Â  
  In view of the beneficial results she obtained in this appeal, we remand this 
  issue to the family court for further consideration. [8] Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., 
  concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Forsythe v. Forsythe, 290 S.C. 253, 255, 349 S.E.2d 405, 
    406 (Ct. App. 1986).

 
   
    [2] Â  Funderburk v. Funderburk, 286 S.C. 129, 131, 332 S.E.2d 
    205, 206 (1985).

 
   
    [3] Â  See Cox v. Cox, 296 S.C. 414, 415, 373 S.E.2d 694, 
    694 (Ct. App. 1988) (â€œAlthough we have jurisdiction in divorce cases to find 
    facts based on our own view of the evidence, we are not required to disregard 
    the findings of the trial judge who saw and heard the witnesses and was in 
    a better position than we are to evaluate their testimony.â€).

 
   
    [4] Â  See Wilson v. Ball, 337 S.C. 493, 497, 523 S.E.2d 
    804, 806 (Ct. App. 1999) (noting the burden of proof to establish incompetency 
    is generally on the party alleging its existence).

 
   
    [5] Â  See Polin v. Polin, 295 S.C. 129, 130, 367 S.E.2d 
    433, 434 (1988) (rejecting the appellantâ€™s claim that he had not agreed to 
    a property settlement freely and voluntarily and noting that both parties 
    acknowledged otherwise at trial). 

 
   
    [6] Â  275 S.C. 76, 268 S.E.2d 30 (1980).Â  Although the supreme court decided 
    Drawdy before issuing its landmark decision in Moseley v. Mosier, 
    279 S.C. 348, 306 S.E.2d 624 (1983), we have found no reason to believe that 
    Moseley or any subsequent decision has abrogated the duty of a family 
    court to ascertain that a separation agreement is fair before approving it.

 
   
    [7] Â  Drawdy, 275 S.C. at 77, 268 S.E.2d at 30 (emphasis added).

 
   
    [8]  See Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501, 503, 427 S.E.2d 
    665, 666 (1993) (wherein the supreme court reversed this courtâ€™s affirmance 
    of an attorneyâ€™s fee award in a divorce case, noting that the petitioner had 
    prevailed on numerous issues when the court of appeals decided the matter).

Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State of South Carolina,       
Respondent.

Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-066
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott 
  and Assistant Attorney General Christopher L. Newton, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Rodney Arnold filed a petition 
  for a writ of habeas corpus.Â  The trial court dismissed the petition, holding 
  the allegations raised by Arnold could not be raised in a petition for habeas 
  corpus since they were cognizable under the Uniform Post Conviction Procedure 
  Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-27-10 to -160 (2003).Â  Arnold argues on appeal he 
  is entitled to seek relief through habeas corpus because he could not now 
  raise the issues in post-conviction relief proceedings since he had already 
  been through post-conviction relief proceedings and any future applications 
  under the act would be treated as successive and since he would also be barred 
  by the statute of limitations contained in the act.Â  Arnold does not claim that 
  the issues he now wishes to raise could not have been raised before in a post-conviction 
  relief application. We affirm [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following 
  authorities:Â  Gibson v. State, 329 S.C. 37, 42, 495 S.E.2d 426, 429 (1998) 
  (holding the trial court could entertain a habeas corpus petition if, among 
  other things, the applicant could show that â€œthe issues raised now could not 
  have been raised in their [sic] prior PCR applicationsâ€; Simpson v. State, 
  329 S.C. 43, 46, 495 S.E.2d 429, 431 (1998) (holding â€œa matter which is cognizable 
  under the Act may not be raised by a petition for a writ of habeas corpus before 
  the circuit or other lower courtsâ€); Keeler v. Mauney, 330 S.C. 568, 
  571, 500 S.E.2d 123, 124 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding if â€œ[a] person is procedurally 
  barred from petitioning the circuit court for a writ of habeas corpus where 
  the matter alleged is one which could have been raised in a PCR application 
  . . . his only means of obtaining state habeas corpus relief is to file a petition 
  in the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Courtâ€).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.Â  
  

 
   
    [1] Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues 
    on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
William Barry Chisholm,       
Appellant/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Susan Elaine Chisholm,       
Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-067
Heard November 16, 2004 â€“ Filed January 
  25, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Timothy E. Madden, of Greenville, for Appellant-Respondent. 

David Alan Wilson and Kenneth C. Porter, both of Greenville, 
  for Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is a cross-appeal from 
  a divorce action.Â  William Barry Chisholm, the husband, argues the family court 
  erred in: (1) declining to grant him a divorce on the ground of adultery, (2) 
  granting custody of the partiesâ€™ minor child to Susan Elaine Chisholm, the wife, 
  (3) refusing to expand his visitation rights, (4) ordering him to bear sole 
  financial responsibility for the childâ€™s private school expenses, (5) finding 
  a portion of an IRA was marital property, and (6) declining his request for 
  attorneyâ€™s fees and awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to the wife.Â  The wife argues the 
  family court erred in awarding the husband sole ownership of the marital home 
  and in refusing to increase the marital estate by $10,000.00.Â  We affirm in 
  part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTS
The parties married in 1979.Â  Both 
  were employed and had limited assets, including retirement funds.Â  Before the 
  marriage, the husband purchased a home that would become the marital residence.Â  
  Two children were born of the marriage, one of whom was still a minor at the 
  time of the final hearing. 
In the spring of 2000, the wife reacquainted 
  herself with a male friend from high school.Â  For several months, the wife, 
  either directly or through the partiesâ€™ older child, communicated with this 
  individual through letters, electronic mail, and telephone.Â  Eventually, the 
  two revealed their mutual and long-standing affections for each other and, in 
  August 2000, arranged a clandestine meeting at a motel, where they engaged in 
  sexual relations with each other.Â  
For months, the wife concealed her adultery from 
  the husband; however, tensions arose in the partiesâ€™ relationship, and she began 
  acting erratic and unstable.Â  In October 2000, the wife was admitted to the 
  hospital, where she was diagnosed with recurrent major depression and placed 
  on medication.Â  After her release from the hospital, the parties resumed living 
  together; however, they never really reconciled and tensions escalated.Â  
In July 2001, the husband filed for divorce on 
  the ground of adultery. [1] Â  He also sought custody of the 
  partiesâ€™ younger child and equitable apportionment of the marital property.Â  
  In her answer and counterclaim, the wife admitted adultery and sought custody.Â  
  At trial, both parties amended their pleadings to seek a no-fault divorce on 
  the ground of a one year separation; however, the husband did not abandon the 
  fault ground of adultery.Â  
After hearing evidence on the contested 
  issues, the family court granted a no-fault divorce.Â  The wife received custody 
  of the partiesâ€™ minor child, and the marital property was divided equally between 
  the parties.Â  The husband received liberal visitation and was ordered to pay 
  child support, including all private school expenses.Â  The family court granted 
  the husband a special interest in the marital home and awarded attorneyâ€™s fees 
  to the wife.Â  Both parties unsuccessfully filed post-trial motions under Rule 
  59(e) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, and this appeal followed. 

LAW/ANALYSIS
The Husbandâ€™s Appeal
1.Â  The husband argues the family court erred 
  in granting a no-fault divorce instead of a divorce on the ground of adultery.Â  
  We disagree.Â  
â€œ[A] divorce is not a prize given in recognition 
  of a victory in a contest.â€ [2] Â  Here, assuming without deciding 
  that the wifeâ€™s adultery was the immediate cause of the breakup of the marriage, 
  the grant of a no-fault divorce did not prejudice the husband.Â  The wife had 
  waived her right to seek alimony, and the family court stated it considered 
  the wifeâ€™s admitted adultery and found her misconduct did not affect the economic 
  condition of the parties. [3] Â  
  Furthermore, although the husband may be correct that the family court was able 
  to grant a divorce on the ground of a one-year separation only because docket 
  constraints prevented this matter from being heard at an earlier date, we fail 
  to see how this circumstance would entitle him to a divorce on a fault ground.Â  
  Finally, the husband does not suggest that spiritual or other considerations 
  proscribe him from obtaining a divorce on the ground of a one-year separation.
2.Â  Second, the husband contends the trial court erred 
  in failing to award him custody of the partiesâ€™ minor child.Â  We find no reason 
  to reverse the family courtâ€™s decision.
â€œThe welfare of the child and what is in his/her 
  best interest is the primary, paramount and controlling consideration of the 
  court in all child custody controversies.â€ [4] Â  â€œHowever, where evidence is 
  disputed [in a family court matter], the appellate court may adhere to the findings 
  of the trial judge, who saw and heard the witnesses.â€ 
  [5] Â  In particular, an appellate court â€œshould be reluctant to substitute 
  its own evaluation of the evidence on child custody for that of the trial court.â€ 
  [6] Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve an appellant of the burden 
  to convince this court that the family court erred in its factual findings and 
  conclusions. [7] 
Here, the family court heard extensive testimony 
  on the custody issue from the parties, mental health professionals, and the 
  guardian ad litem.Â  Mental health professionals testified that, although the 
  child would be fine with either parent, the wife had been his primary caregiver.Â  
  We hold the family court properly considered evidence on the strengths and weaknesses 
  of each parent and therefore affirm the finding that the childâ€™s best interests 
  would be served by placing him in the wifeâ€™s custody.Â  
3.Â  Alternatively, the husband argues that if the 
  family courtâ€™s decision regarding custody is affirmed, he is entitled to more 
  extensive visitation.Â  We agree.Â  
â€œ[V]isitation is addressed to the broad discretion 
  of the family court.â€ [8] Â  Nevertheless, as with child custody, the welfare 
  and best interests of the child are the primary considerations in determining 
  visitation. [9] Â  
The family court initially granted the husband 
  visitation in accordance with â€œJudge Brownâ€™s Standard Visitation Order,â€ which 
  was attached to and incorporated into the appealed order.Â  After the husband 
  moved to alter or amend the judgment, the family court amended the order as 
  follows:Â  â€œ[The husband] shall have such additional visitation with the partiesâ€™ 
  minor child, as the parties may agree.â€Â  Notwithstanding this revision, we hold 
  the evidence indicates the childâ€™s best interests would be served by granting 
  the husband specified visitation over and above what he would receive in a standard 
  visitation order.Â  The husband had maintained an active role in the childâ€™s 
  life.Â  Furthermore, although the wife expressed a desire that the husband have 
  liberal visitation with the child, it was evident that the parties did not communicate 
  well.Â  We therefore remand the issue of visitation to the family court with 
  directions to grant the husband liberal visitation at specified times.
4.Â  We agree with the husband that the 
  family court erred in ordering him to bear sole financial responsibility for 
  the childâ€™s private school expenses without making an adjustment in his child 
  support obligation.Â  
The husband maintained the child should 
  continue to attend private school and testified that he would â€œdo whatever it 
  takesâ€ to enable the child to maintain this privilege.Â  The wife, however, did 
  not believe that private schooling was necessary.Â  We find it significant that 
  the family court agreed with the husband that it was in the childâ€™s best interest 
  to remain in private school and that the wife did not appeal this finding.Â  
  Moreover, the record supports this determination.Â  In particular, we note (1) 
  the child attended this particular school all his life and was already in high 
  school when this case came to trial; and (2) the child had been diagnosed with 
  ADHD, making a private school, with its smaller classes and more individualized 
  attention, a preferable choice to a public school.
The child support guidelines require 
  the parties to share in the support of a child proportionate to the income earned 
  by each of them. [10] Â  In addition, 
  the regulations expressly provide that payment of education expenses can be 
  a possible reason for deviation from the child support guidelines. 
  [11] Â  We therefore reverse the child support decision and remand this matter 
  to the family court with instructions either to allocate the private school 
  expenses between the parties on a pro rata basis or in the alternative to grant 
  the husband a downward adjustment in his support obligation if he is ordered 
  to pay more than his pro rata share of these expenses.
5.Â  The husband next argues $35,357 of 
  an IRA was nonmarital property and thus improperly included in the marital estate.Â  
  We agree.Â  
Property acquired by either party prior 
  to the marriage is generally nonmarital property. 
  [12] Â  In some circumstances, however, nonmarital property may be transmuted 
  into marital property if (1) it becomes so commingled with marital property 
  as to be untraceable; (2) it is jointly titled; or (3) it is utilized by the 
  parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence 
  an intent by the parties to make it marital property. [13] Â  â€œTransmutation is a matter of intent to 
  be gleaned from the facts of each case, and the spouse claiming transmutation 
  must produce objective evidence showing that, during the marriage, the parties 
  themselves regarded the property as the common property of the marriage.â€ 
  [14] Â  
The husband testified in detail about 
  the retirement assets he owned at the time of the marriage, the manner in which 
  they were invested, the records he maintained during the marriage, and the mathematical 
  computation of the premarital component of his IRA, with growth on that portion 
  during the marriage.Â  Moreover, notwithstanding the commingling and the fact 
  that the husband managed the wifeâ€™s retirement funds as well as his own, we 
  hold the wife failed to make a prima facie case that the parties 
  themselves regarded the funds as the common property of the marriage. 
  [15] Â  
 Finally, the husband argues the family 
  court erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to the wife and in denying attorneyâ€™s 
  fees to him.Â  In view of the beneficial results obtained by the husband in this 
  appeal, we remand this issue to the family court for further consideration. [16] 
The Wifeâ€™s Appeal
1.Â  The wife argues 
  the family court erred in awarding the husband sole ownership of the marital 
  home after finding the home was transmuted into marital property.Â  We disagree.Â  
  Â Â  
â€œA family court may 
  grant a spouse title to the marital home as part of the equitable distribution.â€ 
  [17] Â  The family court, in dividing the marital assets, â€œmust give weight 
  in such proportion as it finds appropriate to all of the following factors [including] 
  the desirability of awarding the family home as part of [the] equitable distribution.â€ 
  [18] Â  
On review, this court 
  looks to the fairness of the overall apportionment, and if the end result is 
  equitable, the fact that this court might have weighed specific factors differently 
  than did the trial court is irrelevant. [19] Â  This court will affirm an 
  equitable apportionment if it is apparent that the family court was cognizant 
  of the statutory factors. [20] Â  
The family court found 
  the husband had a â€œspecial equityâ€ in the marital residence because he paid 
  a $25,000 down payment on the home before the marriage, had funds available 
  to pay the full purchase price, and used those funds to pay the debt within 
  five years.Â  Although the residence was valued at $295,000, the total equity 
  was only $75,500.Â  In addition, the husband assumed sole responsibility for 
  all indebtedness under the order.Â  In view of these factors, we hold the decision 
  to award ownership of the marital residence to the husband is fair and equitable.
2.Â  The wife also argues the family court 
  should have included as a marital asset $10,000 that the husband withdrew from 
  a marital account shortly before commencing this litigation.Â  We disagree.Â  
  The wife alleges the funds were withdrawn in contemplation of the divorce action; 
  however, the husband, although acknowledging that he paid his attorney a retainer 
  fee of $10,000, never admitted that the money taken from the account was used 
  for this purpose, suggesting instead that it may have been spent on their childâ€™s 
  private school tuition.Â  No documentation, such as a cancelled check, was provided 
  to enable the family court to determine whether or not the husband had improperly 
  liquidated this asset.Â  Having been provided with no plausible explanation as 
  to why the wife could not have procured such evidence herself, we are reluctant 
  to disturb the family courtâ€™s refusal to find the funds in dispute are part 
  of the marital estate. [21] 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, 
  AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, 
  JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1] Â  Although the wife confessed her affair and already had her emotional 
    breakdown, the husband waited until their older child graduated before seeking 
    a divorce.

 
   
    [2] Â  Miles v. Miles, 303 S.C. 33, 35, 397 S.E.2d 790, 791 (Ct. 
    App. 1990); see also Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 197, 363 
    S.E.2d 404, 406 (Ct. App. 1987) (rejecting a husbandâ€™s contention that he 
    should have been awarded a divorce on his counterclaim when his wife received 
    a divorce on the ground of a one-year separation and noting that the granting 
    of a divorce to the husband on the ground of adultery would not have dissolved 
    the marriage any more completely).

 
   
    [3] Â  See Woodside v. Woodside, 290 S.C. 366, 374, 350 S.E.2d 
    407, 412 (Ct. App. 1990) (stating that a spouseâ€™s marital misconduct becomes 
    important in equitable distribution only when â€œthe conduct . . . is such that 
    it throws upon the other party marital burdens beyond the norms to be expected 
    in the marital relationshipâ€).

 
   
    [4] Â  Cook v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 136, 140, 245 S.E.2d 612, 614 (1978).

 
   
    [5] Â  Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 
    157 (1996).

 
   [6] Â  Id. at 10, 471 S.E.2d at 157.Â  

 
   [7] Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 
    522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979).Â  

 
   
    [8] Â  Paparella v. Paparella, 340 S.C. 186, 191, 531 S.E.2d 297, 
    300 (Ct. App. 2000).

 
   [9] Â  Woodall, 322 S.C. at 12, 471 S.E.2d at 
    158.

 
   
    [10]  27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4710 and -4750 (Supp. 2004).

 
   
    [11]  See id. 114-4710B(1) (stating â€œ[e]ducational expenses 
    for the child(ren) . . . (i.e., those incurred for private, parochial, or 
    trade schools, other secondary schools, or post-secondary education where 
    there is tuition or related costs)â€ can be â€œ[a] possible reason[ ] for deviationâ€).

 
   [12]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-70-473(2) (Supp. 2004).

 
   [13]  Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 338, 
    569 S.E.2d 393, 398 (Ct. App. 2002), cert. denied (June 12, 2003).

 
   
    [14]  Widman v. Widman, 348 S.C. 97, 117, 557 S.E.2d 693, 703-04 
    (Ct. App. 2001).

 
   
    [15]  See Wannamaker v. Wannamaker, 305 S.C. 36, 40, 406 
    S.E.2d 180, 182 (Ct. App. 1991) (â€œ[T]he mere commingling of funds does not 
    automatically make them marital funds.â€).

 
   
    [16]  See Sexton v. Sexton, 310 S.C. 501, 503, 427 S.E.2d 
    665, 666 (1993) (wherein the supreme court reversed this courtâ€™s affirmance 
    of an attorneyâ€™s fee award in a divorce case, noting that the petitioner prevailed 
    on numerous issues when the court of appeals decided the matter).

 
    [17] Craig v. Craig, 
    358 S.C. 548, 558, 595 S.E.2d 837, 841 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  

 
   [18]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(10) (Supp. 2004).

 
   
    [19]  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 
    107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).

 
   
    [20]  Doe v. Doe, 324 S.C. 492, 502, 478 S.E.2d 854, 859 
    (Ct. App. 1996).Â  

 
   
    [21]  See Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 
    541, 541 (1981) (stating that, notwithstanding the scope of review in an equity 
    matter, an appellate court is not required â€œto disregard the findings below 
    nor ignore the better vantage point the trial judge occupies in determining 
    witness credibilityâ€ and â€œ[t]he burden is upon the appellant to convince this 
    Court that the trial judge erred in his findings of factâ€).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT
BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING
EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), 
  SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Carolina Outdoor Development, LLC,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Transportation,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Jasper County
Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-072
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  26, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Darrell T. Johnson, Jr. and Mills Lane Morrison, Jr., both of Hardeeville, for 
  Appellant.
Barbara Munig Wessinger, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Carolina Outdoor Development, 
  LLC (Carolina Outdoor) appeals the circuit court order affirming the denial 
  of three commercial outdoor advertising permits under the South Carolina Highway 
  Advertising Control Act (the Act).Â  See S.C. Code Ann. 57-25-110â€“710 
  (Supp. 2004). Carolina Outdoor argues substantial evidence does not support 
  the underlying decision, and the court erred in finding no violation of Carolina 
  Outdoorâ€™s equal protection rights.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In February 2001, Carolina Outdoor applied to the 
  South Carolina Department of Transportation (DOT) for permits needed to erect 
  three commercial outdoor advertising signs on unzoned commercial property Carolina 
  Outdoor owned in the vicinity of Interstate 26 in Calhoun County.Â  Carolina 
  Outdoor claimed it qualified for the permits because its tenant, Matthews Auto 
  Service [1] , engaged in commercial activity on the subject 
  property.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§57-25-140(A)(8) (Supp. 2004) (Permitting 
  certain outdoor advertising signs on unzoned commercial or industrial areas 
  along interstate or federal-aid primary highways).Â  DOT denied the permits, 
  relying on an exception for businesses engaged in â€œactivities not visible from 
  the main traveled way.â€Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§57-25-120(5)(f) (Supp. 2004).Â  
  Specifically, it found that Matthews Auto Serviceâ€™s business activities were 
  not â€œvisible from the main traveled wayâ€ except to a partial extent in fall 
  and winter months when leaves had fallen from trees located between Matthews 
  Auto Service and Interstate 26.
Carolina Outdoor appealed to the South Carolina 
  Administrative Law Court (ALC) [2] 
  , which conducted a hearing in May 2001.Â  In August 2001, the ALC affirmed 
  the DOTâ€™s decision in a written order.Â  Carolina Outdoor then appealed to the 
  circuit court, which conducted a hearing and subsequently affirmed the ALCâ€™s 
  order.Â  The circuit court denied Carolina Outdoorâ€™s Rule 59(e) motion for reconsideration.Â  
  This appeal followed.
SCOPE OF REVIEW
â€œThis court must affirm an administrative agencyâ€™s 
  decision if the decision is supported by substantial evidence and we may not 
  substitute our judgment for that of the agency upon questions for which there 
  is room for difference of intelligent opinion.â€Â  Smith v. Newberry County 
  Tax Assessor, 350 S.C. 572, 577-78, 567 S.E.2d 501, 504 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence, but evidence which, 
  considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the 
  conclusion the agency reached.â€Â  Id. at 578, 567 S.E.2d at 504 (quoting 
  Grayson v. Carter Rhoad Furniture, 317 S.C. 306, 309, 454 S.E.2d 320, 
  321 (1995)).
DISCUSSION
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Visibility 
Carolina Outdoor first argues that substantial 
  evidence does not exist to support a finding that Matthews Auto Service was 
  unqualified to receive commercial outdoor advertising permits because it engaged 
  in â€œactivities not visible from the main traveled way.â€Â  We disagree.
The Act regulates â€œthe erection and maintenance 
  of outdoor advertising signs adjacent to the interstate and federal-aid primary 
  [highway] systemsâ€ in South Carolina.Â  Daisy Outdoor Adver. Co. v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 352 S.C. 113, 117, 572 S.E.2d 462, 464 (Ct. App. 
  2002).Â  The Act limits the placement of commercial outdoor advertising signs 
  to specific areas, including â€œunzoned commercial areas.â€Â  Id. at 117, 
  572 S.E.2d at 465.Â  Business activities that do not qualify property as an unzoned 
  commercial area includes â€œactivities not visible from the main traveled way.â€Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§57-25-210(5)(f) (Supp. 2003).Â Â  DOT regulations define 
  â€œvisibleâ€ as â€œcapable of being seen, and readily recognized as a sign or commercial 
  or industrial activity by a person of normal visual acuity.â€Â  25A S.C. Code 
  Ann. Regs. 63-342(HH) (Supp. 2004);Â  U.S. Outdoor Advertising, Inc. v. South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 324 S.C. 1, 3, 481 S.E.2d 112, 113 (1997).
Here, Carolina Outdoorâ€™s argument essentially 
  hinges on whether Matthews Auto Service was â€œcapable of being seenâ€ from Interstate 
  26 and â€œreadily recognized [as a commercial activity] by a person of normal 
  visual acuity.â€Â  The ALC concluded that this condition was not sufficiently 
  established.Â  It was noted, however, that the location was partially visible 
  during the colder months when foliage had fallen from trees located between 
  Matthews Auto Service and Interstate 26.Â  It was determined, therefore, that 
  Matthews Auto Service was not â€œvisibleâ€ within the meaning of the Act, and thus 
  unqualified for the permits Carolina Outdoor sought.Â  We agree for the reasons 
  articulated in the ALCâ€™s detailed and well-reasoned order, which we adopt and 
  incorporate by reference herein.Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Equal Protection Violation
Carolina Outdoor also argues that denial 
  of the permits violated its equal protection rights under the Fourteenth Amendment 
  to the United States Constitution because permits were granted to others â€œwhere 
  the qualifying business [was] equally or less visible and identifiableâ€ than 
  Matthews Auto Service.Â  However, Carolina Outdoor fails to provide any specific 
  examples of businesses located on similar sites that were treated differently.Â  
  Thus, we find that Carolina Outdoor failed to meet its burden of proof with 
  respect to this issue.Â  See 25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-349(M) (Supp. 
  2004) (â€œThe applicant shall bear the burden of showing that [DOT] should issue 
  the permit.â€).
AFFIRMED. 
HUFF, KITTREDGE, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  The name â€œMatthewsâ€ is spelled differently in many places 
    in the record.Â  Because â€œMatthewsâ€ appears in Carolina Outdoorâ€™s permit applications, 
    we adopt this spelling.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  At the time, the ALC was named the South Carolina Administrative 
    Law Judge Division.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Lester Joe Puckett, Sr.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
William George, Jr., also known as G.G. George,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2005-UP-073
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  27, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James Mixon Griffin, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Charles S. Bradford, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This is an appeal from a grant 
  of summary judgment in a foreclosure action.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
In 1999, William George contracted 
  with Larry Puckett to purchase Joeâ€™s Mini-Mall.Â  Both the title to the real 
  estate and the closing statement identify the sales price as $1,100,000.Â  George 
  made a down payment of $100,000 and signed a promissory note for $1,000,000.Â  
  At the real estate closing, George also executed a separate $150,000 mortgage 
  note. [1] Â  In October 2000, Puckett filed an action against George Properties, 
  LLC, for the foreclosure of Joeâ€™s Mini-Mall.Â  On June 13, 2001, the court awarded 
  Puckett a judgment of $1,064,044.45 and ordered the property be sold at a public 
  auction.Â  Puckett purchased the property at the sale for $2,500.Â  George Properties, 
  LLC, did not appeal the decree of foreclosure and sale in the action concerning 
  Joeâ€™s Mini Mall.Â Â Â  
Seven months prior to 
  the filing of that case, Puckett filed an action against George seeking to collect 
  on the $150,000 mortgage note.Â  The trial court granted Puckettâ€™s motion for 
  summary judgment.Â  George appealed the decision to this court and we affirmed 
  the trial court.Â  Puckett v. George, 2002-UP-671 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When 
  Puckett initiated actions to collect on the mortgage note judgment, George filed 
  a Rule 60(b) motion for relief from judgment, claiming he should get credit 
  against the judgment for the amount that the fair market value of the property 
  exceeded the foreclosure judgment amount.Â  The trial court denied the motion 
  based on its finding that the mortgage note â€œwas not related to a real estate 
  transaction, but to the sale of goodwill and other intangible property.â€Â  This 
  appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
George claims the trial court erred 
  in failing to reduce the judgment on the mortgage note by the value of the property 
  obtained by the mortgagee in a prior foreclosure action on the promissory note.Â  
  We disagree. 
The $150,000 note signed by George was 
  unrelated to the real estate transaction and was clearly a separate debt on 
  which Puckett foreclosed.Â  The attorney for the real estate closing of Joeâ€™s 
  Mini-Mall testified by affidavit that â€œthe note represented the intangible valueâ€ 
  of the property, which included among other things, goodwill and location.Â  
  He further stated, â€œThe exact terms of the note were something that had been 
  discussed and agreed to, in [his] presence, several months prior to the actual 
  document closing.â€Â  Furthermore, Puckettâ€™s accountantâ€™s affidavit cited the 
  total purchase price of Joeâ€™s Mini-Mall as $1,250,000, a combined total price 
  of the note for the real estate and the note currently in dispute.Â  In its order 
  for summary judgment, the trial court found â€œno reference in the promissory 
  note to any real estate transaction.â€Â  Finally, this court affirmed the trial 
  courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on this same issue.Â  
Any unappealed portion of a judgment is 
  the law of the case and must therefore be affirmed.Â  Tolerâ€™s Cove Homeowners 
  Assâ€™n, Inc. v. Trident Constr. Co., 355 S.C. 605, 610, 586 S.E.2d 581, 584 
  (2003); Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 398, 
  593 S.E.2d 183, 189 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  George did not appeal this courtâ€™s decision; 
  he simply tried to make the same argument to the trial court once Puckett attempted 
  to enforce the judgment.Â  The trial court and the court of appeals have found 
  the notes to be separate and distinct debts.Â  In keeping with Tolerâ€™s Cove 
  and Rumpf, these factual and legal conclusions are â€œlaw of the case.â€Â  
  George was not entitled to a reduction of judgment on the mortgage note by the 
  value of the property obtained by the mortgagee in the prior foreclosure action 
  on the promissory note.Â Â  Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s 
  denial of relief from judgment is
 AFFIRMED.  
  [2] 
HEARN, C.J., GOOLSBY and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Throughout his brief, George refers to the $150,000 note as the mortgage 
    note, and the $1,000,000 note as the promissory note.Â  To prevent confusion, 
    this opinion will identify the documents in the same manner.

 
   
    [2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  
  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS 
  PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Varanda Odom Roberson,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Christopher Roberson,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Peter R. Nuessle, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2005-UP-074
Submitted January 1, 2005 â€“ Filed January 
  31, 2005 


AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Vicki Johnson Snelgrove, of Aiken, for Appellant.
Christopher Roberson and Patricia Thomas James, both of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: In this domestic action, Varanda 
  Roberson appeals the family courtâ€™s failure to recognize her relationship with 
  Christopher Roberson as a common law marriage.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Varanda and Christopher Robersonâ€™s relationship began with the pair 
  dating in high school.Â  After conceiving a child in 1992, Varanda and Christopher 
  moved in together, living in this capacity for approximately ten years interrupted 
  only by two periods of separation.Â  During this period of cohabitation, the 
  parties had four more children.Â  Sometime during the relationship, Varanda began 
  using â€œRobersonâ€ as her surname and Christopherâ€™s family once listed her as 
  his spouse in an obituary.Â  School records for the children, who were all named 
  â€œRoberson,â€ listed the parties as â€œMr. and Mrs. Roberson.â€ Christopher sent 
  flowers addressing her as Varanda Roberson and the two registered for a vacation 
  under the name of Roberson.Â  
 In January 2003, Christopher left the 
  home he shared with Varanda and the children.Â  Varanda brought an action in 
  March 2003 seeking custody of the children, child support, alimony, and equitable 
  division of the marital assets.Â  After a temporary hearing deciding custody, 
  visitation, and child support, the family court bifurcated the issues at trial 
  with the intention to hear initially only the common law marriage issue.Â  After 
  a trial, the family court found that no common law marriage existed and therefore 
  the court lacked authority to divide the property.Â  Varanda appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The issue of common law marriage sounds 
  in law. Richland Mem'l Hosp. v. English, 295 S.C. 511, 513, 369 S.E.2d 
  395, 396 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  Our review in this case is limited to a determination 
  of whether or not there is any evidence to support the findings of the trial 
  judge. Weathers v. Bolt, 293 S.C. 486, 488, 361 S.E.2d 773, 774 (Ct. 
  App. 1987). Because this action sounds in law, and the existence of a common 
  law marriage is a question of fact, this court is bound by the lower courtâ€™s 
  factual findings, and its credibility determinations. Barker v. Baker, 
  330 S.C. 361, 370, 499 S.E.2d 503, 508 (Ct. App. 1998). We must affirm if any 
  evidence supports the lower courtâ€™s findings. Tarnowski v. Lieberman, 
  348 S.C. 616, 619, 560 S.E.2d 438, 440 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
 Varanda argues that the trial court committed 
  error by failing to recognize a common law marriage existed with Christopher.Â  
  We disagree.
Section 20-7-420(5) of the South Carolina 
  Code (1985) grants the family court exclusive jurisdiction to hear and determine 
  the validity of marriages.Â  â€œIn South Carolina, a common-law marriage exists 
  if the parties intend to enter into a marriage contract.â€Â  Barker at 
  367, 499 S.E.2d at 506.Â  â€œIt is essential to a common law marriage that there 
  shall be a mutual agreement between the parties to assume toward each other 
  the relation of husband and wife.Â  Cohabitation without such an agreement does 
  not constitute marriage.â€Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 235 S.C. 542, 550, 112 
  S.E.2d 647, 651 (1960).Â  â€œA valid common law marriage requires that the facts 
  and circumstances show an intention on the part of both parties to enter into 
  a marriage contract.â€Â  Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543, 545, 466 S.E.2d 
  373, 375 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The party claiming a common law marriage must prove 
  it by a preponderance of the evidence.Â  Yarbrough v. Yarbrough, 280 S.C. 
  546, 551, 314 S.E.2d 16, 18-19 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  However, direct evidence of 
  the partiesâ€™ intent is not often available, thus the existence of a common-law 
  marriage is frequently proved by circumstantial evidence.Â  Barker at 
  367-368, 499 S.E.2d at 507.Â  Typically, the circumstantial evidence relied upon 
  to prove a common-law marriage is the amount of time a couple has lived together 
  and whether the couple publicly held themselves out as husband and wife.Â  Id.Â  
  â€œWhile the presumption of marriage from cohabitation and reputation is ordinarily 
  a rebuttable presumption, the degree of proof to overcome it is generally very 
  high, especially where the parties have cohabitated as husband and wife for 
  a long time.â€Â  Owens, 320 S.C. at 546, 466 S.E.2d at 375.Â  â€œThe presumption 
  of marriage can be dispelled only by evidence which is â€˜clear, distinct and 
  satisfactory.â€™â€ Id. (quoting Jeanes v. Jeanes, 255 S.C. 161, 167, 
  177 S.E.2d 537, 540 (1970)).Â  
The family court determined that Christopher presented 
  sufficient evidence that rebutted the presumption of marriage to overcome evidence 
  of the coupleâ€™s long period of cohabitation.Â  The court found several facts 
  of their behavior important: Christopher neglected to place Varandaâ€™s name on 
  the deed or mortgage to a new house he bought, his job health insurance covered 
  his children, but not Varanda, and the parties never established joint ownership 
  of property or joint assets.Â  The court found and the record supports the notion 
  that although Christopher knew Varanda had taken his surname, he was not pleased 
  with the fact and even proposed marriage to her on two occasions, evincing his 
  belief that the parties were not married.Â  As this is an action at law, we are 
  bound by the family courtâ€™s findings of fact unless they are without evidence 
  to support them and we find that in the instant case, sufficient evidence exists.
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

Denis Oâ€™Connor, BBT Financial Services Limited, and Mont Clava Limited,       
Defendants,
Of Whom BBT Financial Services Limited, Third Party Plaintiff, and Denis

James L. Rogers, Jr.,

Unpublished Opinion No.Â 
2005-UP-075
Heard January 12, 2005 â€“ Filed January

DISMISSED


  
    
      
Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for Appellants.
William A. Coates and Carroll H. Roe, Jr., of Greenville, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Denis Oâ€™Connor and BBT Financial 
  Services Limited (â€œBBTâ€) appeal from a protective order limiting Appellantsâ€™ 
  discovery requests to the time period Leatherwood, Walker, Todd & Mann, 
  P.C. (â€œLeatherwoodâ€) represented the Appellants.Â  We dismiss.
FACTS
BBTâ€™s owner, Denis Oâ€™Connor, 
  hired Leatherwood to assist in its purchase of a textile mill from Greenwood 
  Mills.Â  However, the sale fell through and BBT sued Greenwood Mills in federal 
  court.Â  Eventually, the case settled and Leatherwood formally terminated its 
  representation of Oâ€™Connor.Â  Later, Leatherwood brought this action to collect 
  attorneyâ€™s fees from Oâ€™Connor and BBT (Appellants).Â  Appellants counterclaimed 
  for conversion, legal malpractice, and breach of fiduciary duty, and brought 
  a third party complaint against a specific Leatherwood attorney.Â  Appellantsâ€™ 
  claims concern the firmâ€™s connection with a group of investors called Liberty 
  Denim who eventually leased the mill from its new owner and received an option 
  from the new owner to purchase a separate wastewater treatment facility.Â  This 
  appeal follows an order issued by the trial court limiting Appellantsâ€™ discovery 
  from third parties to the time period when Leatherwood represented BBT. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ ANALYSIS
Appellants claim the trial court erred 
  by making factual conclusions that were unrelated and inappropriate to a protection 
  motion, thereby quashing subpoenas seeking relevant information without proper 
  legal justification and resulting in summary judgment as to Appellantsâ€™ counterclaims 
  for malpractice and breach of fiduciary duty.Â  However, an order denying or 
  compelling discovery is not directly appealable because it is an intermediate 
  or interlocutory decision not appealable before final judgment under section 
  14-3-330 of the South Carolina Code (1977). Ex Parte Whetstone, 289 S.C. 
  580, 580, 347 S.E.2d 881, 881 (1986).
DISMISSED.
ANDERSON, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.
